div.head: Act. Prim.
div.l: A cuckold? why now it is a common name,
As the shee-gossips are that give it us.
Why doth it not derive, and spread itself.
To all the generations we produce?
Why should not every child of mine be called
Cuckold, as well as Vaster, woman, woman
Thou sad undoer of the fairest building,
That ever earth bragged to be pavement to.
Man, man; the pride of heaven's creation,
Abstract of nature, that in his small volume
Contains the whole world's text, and heaven's impression:
His maker's image, angel's mate, earth's great wonder,
Made to guide all, by woman is brought under.
That harmony, fair nature made to stand,
Is forced out of tune by woman's hand.
A woman hath deformed me. See, I look
Like any beast has horns: an ass may boast
Himself a hornless gentleman before me.
Yet let not clouds of passion choke my reason.
Why? what's a cuckold? let's see: define him:
div.p:
It is a man, whose wife plays the whore. 'zlid, what's that to him? It is all one, as if a proper gentleman should ride on a halting jade; or a good musician play on a broken fiddle. O but 'twill be said: woman could not be so light a ship, if her husband could well ballast her. It is his insufficiency. A pox it is.
Had she Hercules to her husband, she would enter the lists with some crinkle-hammed tilting courtier. Well then,
div.l: I see no reason, that a woman's evil,
Should thus transform man to a horned devil,
No: 'twas Actaeon's lusts, and not his wife,
That so bestagged him. Hence sprouts all my shame.
Fuller of truth than age, this rule hath been:
"Nothing deforms a man, but his own sin.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir, my mother prays —

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: No more of her. Her prayers.
Are putrid sacrifices: like foul airs,
Too thick to mount up to yond glorious feeling.
"When black hands are reared up, heaven has no feeling.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: She is your wife, my mother, sir.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: What then sir?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Nothing, but that you wrong her, o my conscience.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: O 'tis a brave puritan-world, when boys talk of conscience! Conscience must lie at the stake, when they play but at blowpoint. Sirrah, as you love your conscience, hate a wife. Zlid, if I thought thou wouldst marry, I would unbless thee, as I have disinherited thee already: get bastards, as I would ha' got thee. A woman may serve to lie withal: none good enough to marry.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O were you not my father, I would let
This passion out of your impostumed heart —
Why should not I forget, that your blood moves
In any veins of mine; when you forgo
The reason of a father, husband, man?
And stick degeneration on your name?
If I sail ill, know your example steered
My voyage and my vessel. Fathers are more
Than private men: their lives are the set copies.
Their children write by; and should there give
Their imitation patterns how to live.
Hell's a sad place, they say: — o, I'll dare never
To follow my own father leading thither.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Sirrah, call your mother. This boy's a Puritan.
I that had ne'er loved myself to be thought good,
Am highly pleased to see it in my blood.
From whom derives this sprig such fruitful juice;
The father being bad, the mother worse.
Sure, he did suck this goodness from his nurse.
Poor boy, my riot has undone thee: poor
Thou'rt made by me, I by a wife turned whore.
My state is mortgaged to the usurous hand
Of gripe: my goods are wasted: all my hopes life
Breathes thus: having sold all, I'll sell my wife.
sp.p: you're welcome, looseness.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Looseness sir? O hell!
She is my mother; pray you, use her well.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Be gone.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I cannot sir.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Good son, a way.
A father gives command.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I must obey.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Make much of you? I will, I will. Never man made more of his wife, when he sold her to her smock. I'll sell thy flesh too Gipsy.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Dear husband, I am yet clear; o do not you
Force me to sin, I'll be for over true.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: True? true to the brothel, to the spittle, to the grave.
Thou art death's agent: a whore is one of his beadles.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Heaven pardon your black slanders.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Come, I'm poor.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Who made you?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Thou, my content, turned whore.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I'll work, or beg for you.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: No, thou hast wrought
Too much already. Here, here's thy work.
Wilt thou do one thing?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Then swear.
And keep thy oath. I'll travel to the wars,
And turn thee up, as some captains wont; and try,
If thou canst live by thy old trade, or die.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Will you forsake me then?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Yes, and am just.
Since thou forsook'st me, and thine innocence,
be thy reward proportioned I must hence.
Whiles thou wast good, to thee I had free desire.
Now thou art proved a whore receive thy hire.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Take place, thou tyrant will. Thick woes here hover.
My state is lower than fate can recover.
My obedience waits your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Hoh, within there.
Aunt mermaid I have brought you the girl
I promised. Is the money ready?

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: By that little honesty I have to swear by; a handsome wench. I must pay fifty pound for her: but if she were as young, as fair, I would get five hundred pound by her within this month.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Aunt, pray use her well: she's my own sister.

Be petulant you whore, sprightly frolic — as a Dutch tannakin. — or — this woman is a bawd, a very bawd; you like her the better for that. Come, skip about, quick silver: dance like a courtesan, or I'll fiddle ye. You ha' more tricks in private, than a fencer can teach a lord, or the devil a fencer. Life, do you pule? I must have fifty pound for you: do y' hear? Let your heels caper, and your tongue grow wanton, or by these horns I'll gore you — aunt, she's somewhat sick of that rare disease, called modesty. But in private she's more insatiate than a Puritan.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: How old are you, fair sister?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Not sixteen.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: About some six and forty.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: O you witch — aunt, she lies eight and twenty, at least
sp.l: Hark ye sister, —
Please this old hag, make her believe you're right,
And answerable to her Stygian spells:
Or I will bear thee to an army, and there
Ha' thy sod flesh sold, lent; and prostituted,
And myself cuckolded forty times a day.
Leave this forced soberness — aunt, will you hear her speak?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I can skip lighter than the wanton doe,
And jerk it through the dale,
I cannot hold, neither my tongue, nor heels,
(Nor nails from scratching out a lecher's eyes)
sure, I am composed most of the nimbler elements:
But little water in me, far less earth, some air,
To keep me humid, mutable, and tender,
And apt for convolution: but their mixture
Is scarce discernible, th' are so dispersed.
For my predominant quality is all fire,
Pure, radiant, subtle fire.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: I have oft seen a couple of light heels
Carry a sober head: a woman's tongue
Read lectures of civility; her face
A printed book, each dimple a sweet line,
That doth to good the readers eye incline,
Never till now a body forced to do,
What the poor mind loathes to consent unto.
She danceth weeping, laughs and sighs in pain.
So I have seen ( methinks ) sunshine in rain.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Enough, I long to employ her. Cousin, here's the money. She's mine. What's your name?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Florence.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Florence. I like the name well.
It's a good lucky name to make a whore on. You'll stay with me, Florence.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Till you are weary of me. I'll but take leave of my brother, and follow you.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: What with me?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Am I not worthy of one kiss?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: There — now be gone.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Be gone? Death could not speak a word more fatal.
Yet one more — so now farewell —
Unjust — unkind — my woe-divining heart.
By this we first embraced, by this we part.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: I am a villain, but she makes me weep.
Why do I think she's false? I never saw't.
Tut, all bells ring that tune. It is too true.
I told her that this fifty pound should carry me to the wars;
But I have a battle to fight ere I go.
Old gripe that has the mortgage of my lands,
Lies sick of the gout, and seldom stirs abroad.
Some of that race I'll kill, or leave my own life
In pawn I would have done 't. I ha' challenged
Benjamin gripe the son, whom the world calls
The honest lawyer. He comes.
sp.p: You're the son of a villain.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: If I were, I could not help it.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Thyselfe's a villain.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: It's a rank lie.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Lie? Thou exasperat'st
One mad already, that would have hazard heaven
To make this earth drunk with thy blood.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Its dear, so bought. 'twill not redeem your soul.
Say, with deep sluices, all these lively springs,
That run through the soft channels of my veins,
Should be exhausted by thee, or thine by me,
And burning malice should be quenched in blood:
He that speeds best, wins what he should abhor,
And glories to be cursed a conqueror.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Let sophisters alone with these distinctions.
Our moderators are our swords: the question,
That calls us forth, as warlike disputants
Beyond decision of the gown-furred peace.
Draw then thy argument, and let's talk indeed.
We cannot reason soundly, till we bleed.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Let's think the terms, on which we venture blood.
Th'effects are weighty, let the cause be good.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Thy father hath undone me, and mine issue.
The law affords no succour: what remains,
But only to let him bleed through thy veins?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: How have I wronged thee?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Ask no more. The state
Of our strife is, thou art his son, I hate.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: No help? let fury arbitrate the rest.
This passion must but centre in one breast.
Yet let's embrace, and pardon; and even love
In hate. O suffer not the dying blood
To prejudice the sad survivors good.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: What unexpected clangor frights the peace
of my delighted solitary walks?
What sons of mischief in their fury tread
These unfrequented paths? — stay — hold.
My sons, hear age but speak; wisdom is old.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Peace, dotard.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: On my knees, which doubling age
Hath scarce left able to support my corpse:
By the remaining tears of forty years
Spent in this penitential order: the last drops,
The drying hand of age hath left to dew
This withered garden: I implore — beseech.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Father, you speak to rocks, or the surd waves.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: Then on this innocent bosom turn your swords,
And ease a weak soul of her tedious portage,
Some hour before her time. O do not fly me.
Let the few drops of my slow-pacing blood,
That stands in my cold channels, expiate yours.
O let a falling trunk redeem two plants.
No remedy? let me exclaim for help.
sp.p: (The devil part you:) if I should now ha' paid for my charity — well: 'twas this church-coat that saved me.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: O thou hast slain me: hold thy conquering hand.
Heavens, you are too just paymasters. Thy sword,
With a fate-signed direction, hath cut short
My hoped fortunes in a longer breath.
But I forgive thee. Fly — stay.
I have two orphans in this hour deprived
Of a bad parent. For their mother — nothing.
She has a trade to live on. O let my dying breath
Beg this one mercy at thy bloodstained hands:
Relieve them with now thine, once their own lands.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Forgive my deed, and by that mercy, I
Depend on for my sins; my mercy shall
Raise up the children for the father's fall. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: He's gone. Now up again. My wounds
Are slight, yet through their windows, hear I breathe
Out all my malice. Noble youth, I love thee.
How little of thy father hast thou in thee!
Now for some strange disguise, till time I find,
To pleasure him that was to me thus kind.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Well, I see there's no living in London, the four winds have conspired to blow all the villainy of the world thither. When I returned from my short travel, I enquired, for the knot of my old companions. But like an old lady, that has much used painting, how suddenly are they broken! I heard of three or four in bedlam. Five or six in Bridewell. Half a score ith' counter. A whole dozen at Tyburn. But o, numbers, numbers, under the hands of barber-surgeons. Some turned squires to a brothel. Others walk Newgate lane. Some cheating in ordinaries. Others prigging in crowds. And the rest, either swom over sea, or drowned upon a hill. Well, I do not like these proceedings; there be so many rubs. I could now beg in Dutch, but it's no speeding language. Now my villainy fails on the sea, I'll try what cheats the land has to work on. I learned some scurvy medicines of our surgeon of the ship: and had no sooner set up my bills in Bedford here; but a gouty cure comes halting to me. Fifty pounds I must have to heal him. Five and twenty I have in pawn: for the rest, I'll leave it with the next quacksalver, that with more skill shall do him as little good.
sp.stage: Enter Gripe halting, nice and thirsty.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Cousin nice, and my man thirsty.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Shall I fetch you some drink, sir?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No. Thy mind runs all oth' pot.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: So 't had need, for you keep me thirsty, spite of my teeth.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Go you two to the under-sheriff; and bid him by virtue of this mortgage, give you possession of Vaster's lands. The beggarly slave has broken with me, and I'll take the forfeit. Go quick, quick. I will not lose an hour.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I'll but go to the church for a little holy-water —

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Be drowned in holy-water.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No, but a little sprinkled sir. We shall have the better success in our business.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I pray thee good nice, dispatch, dispatch.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Ay, come, come master nice. There's good liquour it he house. You may sprinkle your throat with that. Its better than holy-water.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: One thing sir. I do not like going today. Sure 'tis not a lucky time. For the first crow I heard this morning, cried twice. This even, sir, is no good number.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Pox of crows and numbers. If thou hadst given her a piece of carrion, she would ha' cried again. Away.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: I go, sir — stay, what if there be a raven about the ground?
Shall we then take possession? O 'tis an unlucky bird.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Why, let her croak the downfall of his house.
What's that to me? prithee good nice make haste.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nay, too much haste will make one stumble: and that's no good sign.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Now, Valentine, hast all things ready? how now — again?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: A toy comes in my head.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Pox of that head: more toys yet?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: How if a cat sits on the buttery hatch? Thou wouldst proceed no further. My grandam told me that a cat sitting on the hatch, was an ill sign.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Mew. Beat her off, dash out her brains. Good nice be not so curious.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: O sir, it's good doubting the worst.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Are all things ready, Valentine? this fool troubles me worse than the gout.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, the remedy is very painful. I could give a tedious course of physic, worse than any sickness. Keep you fasting sixteen days together, save the diet I give you. Bind you to the post of patience every day ten hours; and have one still pour scalding water on you: purge your very heart out: send your eyes out of their holes, to see how your feet do: make your guts bark worse, than an hundred dogs at a bear-baiting. But my medicine is sharp and short, but passing sure. Sir, there be four kinds of gout.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: No more of kinds. There's no gout kind to any man, I think, but to physicians. Your remedy short-short.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, nothing: specially of no cost. Do y' see this tenpenny nail?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Yes: what of that?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: This nail I must drive through your great toe.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What? through the bone?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, bone and flesh too.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh-oh-give me my money. This medicine's worse than any gout. O good Valentine, your tent's too long — too long.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Then sit and rot: be racked still, I'll be gone.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Nay, good Valentine: would not a sixpenny nail serve?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You'll be physician, will you? If you'll sit down and be cured, so: if not, farewell.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Nay, good Valentine: — even do thy will.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Endure it manfully. It's but a brunt — so.Nails him.you shall sit but a quarter of an hour, till I ha' been at the apothecaries, and then I'll lose you. Now farewell, gouty fool, thou tookest no purge, yet hast a most sharp stool. Pray heavens, this kill him not. Well, let him sit.He takes away his purse with his keysand this shall go with me. I pray sir take your case. This plot has taken; try if some new may hit.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Come-come-valentine. Oh-never was man so far in my bonds, as I am in this physicians. He has nailed me to him. That every whore in London, were but i' my case now. Why Valentine —
O he's come. How now? are you returned? where's my mortgage? out villains, where's my mortgage? O my toe — o my mortgage. I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: methinks you are too fast, sir.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Plague of you and your mortgage. O my heart-it beats so, that it has broke my buttons. I would not be so frighted again to be made your heir. puff.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What's the news thirsty? what, what, good thirsty?

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Let me undo you master.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No, not till I hear of my mortgage. What's the matter? o —

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: The matter? I would not ha' such another cross, for all the crosses i' your purse.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What? o — what? Is my mortgage safe? Hath the under-sheriff done a miracle, and played the honest man? what good thirsty?

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Nothing sir, but a hare crossed the way; and he, poor timorous soul, durst go no further for fear of sprights.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: O rogues, pernicious villains, you conspire to cozen me: get out the nail, thirsty. Hares, and ravens, and devils.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Who has abused you thus sir? could you be so credulous, to think this a receipt good for the gout? Sir, give me leave to help you.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Do, good Ben but not in this, Ben not in this. O my mortgage man, my mortgage — run. I shall lose a day's fruits of my mortgage.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Come sir, respect your health above your gain.
I would not for your wealth have half your pain.
Go in sir, get some broth, look to your wound.
Your mortgage leave to me, I'll keep that sound.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Take my cousin nice with you. Come thirsty, help thirsty.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Now for some cleanly trick to shift my hands
Of this same shallow superstitious fool.
sp.p: Now cozen, I'm sure you are not without an erra pater i' your pocket. They say this is like to be a very strange year.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Most strange, and full of preposterous, prodigious, turbulent, dismal, fatal, amazing, terrifying —

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Bless us. What?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Wonders. The effects whereof will appear in risings, partly biformed, and partly circular, on men's foreheads, and women's mountains.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Is there no sad mortality to ensue?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Yes, my almanac speaks of a most fearful pestilence, especially to happen amongst tailors and gold-end-men.
There's a statute-lace shall undo them i'faith. A tailor's bill shall be no more so deadly as the plagues.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Sirrah nice, I had a dream tonight .

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Passion of my heart! A dream? what? I do not like these dreams.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I'll tell thee what. Methought , my troubled fancy
Led me into a garden proudly decked
With nature's glory, and the sweetest flowers,
that ere my breath sucked up: where the green grass
Tempted my sleepy spirits to soft repose.
There came, methought , a friend (Dead now long since)
And shook me by the hand, and questioned me
Of many sad events, whose conference
So vexed me that I woke. Why standest amazed?
Thou wilt not leave me coz.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Yes, and you were ten cousins. Dream of a garden, and green rushes, and a dead friend's salutation? Cousin, make your will, be ruled and make your will: you cannot live.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Wilt thou be a fool of fate? who can
Prevent the destiny decreed for man? I'll on.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: So will not I. Good coz, I leave you to your destiny. The next news I hear, the lawyer's a dead man. Dreams quoth 'a! and he will not believe a dream, he's an infidel. One night I dreamt that I found gold at a play. Next day I came thither, flattered with these hopes. Zlid, before the prologue had done, I had lost my purse.
sp.l: Coz ▪ if you ha' no faith in dreams, farewell.
I would not dream of heaven, lest I find hell.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: This charm has cast him off, now to my mortgage.
O vaster, thou art dead; thy hapless issue,
Exposed to the bleak air of these cold times.
I have no means to expiate the wrongs,
My cruel father, and myself more bloody,
Have done thee, but by charity to thine,
All the poor pieces that remain of thee.
So with the plasters of our broken good,
We hide the wounds, first having shed the blood.
Within there hoh.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Thou comest upon thy death, infectious issue of the world's plague; if thy blood stained foot enter these doors. Our parents are from home. Till their return, I'll keep possession. Or lose it with my life.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Incensed youth.
Thou fightest 'gainst power with a sword of straw:
As good cope with the devil, as with the law.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Methinks , sir, there should dwell some pity in your look.
O, cast an eye of mercy on the woes,
Of two most wretched orphans; doubly lost,
First in their parents' miseries: but, o! most
In their untimely deaths; for we doubt sore,
We never shall behold their faces more.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: My grief requites you both.
No matter, had it so pleased the high powers,
If that my father had excused yours.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Good sir, forget your strength; and do not triumph over the prostrate fortunes of two wretches,
sp.l: Exposed to unresisted tyranny.
Behold a maiden begging on her knee —

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Rise: that's heaven's due. These arms now thee intwine,
That wish for ever, to be called thine:
A strange new influence runs through my affections,
Into my panting heart; and there enthroned,
Commands my lower faculties to love
This poor distressed virgin. I am flamed
With pity and affection; whether more!
Yet let my senses some cool reason gather:
What, love the daughter, and have slain the father?
(I must: heaven knows I must). See, my loved friends:
My coming to you is for other ends.
My father sent me to invade your lands.
A while stand free redeemed with my hands.
There's money to relieve you: that done, you shall have more.
Despair not: heaven will not forsake the poor.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Right noble son of so professed a foe,
Heaven be as kind to you, as you to our woe.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I burst, if I contain my passion. Fairest virgin,
If thou dar'st credit me, I love thee.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Hold. Here take your kindness back: though we are poor,
My sister was not bred to be a whore.
Forbear to touch her.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Fond youth, thy rage is vain.
Thou'rt young: thy error doth thy virtue stain.
I love her as a wife.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: O do not mock me.
How can I think, you to such fortunes born.
Will look upon a maid, so poor, forlorn?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Alas! that poverty should virtue smother.
Not in my breast. No, I'll still honest be:
Virtue in rags are gold's all one to me.
Censure me both, as you shall find me true,
I'll be your father, and your brother too.
sp.stage: Enter old Gripe brought in a chair, by nice and thirsty.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: So, let me down, till I have seen my new mortgage.
How now son Benjamin, ha' you taken possession?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Of that you cannot dispossess me, sir.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No knave? what wilt thou take my lands before I'm dead?
You are a brave son indeed. But this is the world. If the father be poor, the son would be rid of him, to save charges. If rich, he must have his lands ere his bones be cold.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: They may be cold, for they ha' been rotten these dozen years.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I am very hungry.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: I am very thirsty.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: But dare not eat, because I was dreamed tonight of choking.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Now brother w' are, undone.
The damned father will pervert the son.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Gout, dropsy, lameness, rotten legs can hasten
T'undo the poor. Usurers that sit
Bound to their chairs with charms, and cannot move
But by their porters, can to ill bestir them.
He needs make haste, that is at hell before them.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Ha? for 3. Months?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Indeed sir, by that power you put me in,
In charity to their miserable state,
Orphaned of parents, and of means to live,
I gave them 3. months profit of the lands.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Out villain, charity's a beggar, as thou wilt be. 3. months! three weeks, 3. days, 3. hours had been more charity, then ever I showed, or will show to such beggars. Come nice, thirsty, list me: I'll take possession myself.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I hope sir, you'll not nullify my deed.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Deed me no deeds: I'll nullify thee from being mine heir. Come, help me I say.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Indeed sir, I dare not lift you against the poor.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Where's my man thirsty?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: He's gone in to drink sir.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: O he's a good knave: he has got possession o'th' house.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Of nothing master but the buttery, I.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: As lame as I am, I'll in myself.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sit still you lethargy: y' had better drop —

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Contain yourself, young friend. He is my father,
Let not the warm nest of my love to you,
Hatch up encouragement to my father's wrongs.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You are my stern sir, at your pleasure guide
This tempest-beaten vessel.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Good sir confirm
This work of piety, which I presumed,
On faith of your good nature to afford.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Sirrah, your good nature will bring you to th'almshouse. Thou shalt not inherit a doit of mine. And for you two Kitlins, I'll make you mew ith' jail, and there be any law in England. So this chasing fit hath got me the use of my legs again. O excellent surgeon; would thou wert here again, for the other 25. pounds.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Strange! that same quacksalver has done him good, against his will. How fare you sir?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: The worse for thee bastard. Thou'st too much charity in thee to be the son of old gripe.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Dear brother, yield possession: we'll beg rather,
Than this our worthy friend should lose his father.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sir, be not so incensed: resume your son
Into your former love, and I resign
All right, that his free promise hath made mine.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Come then, nice, thirsty. O brave surgeon, I can go.
O brave mortgage I can enter.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: M. Benjamin, a sober word in private. If this wench want harbour, I care not if I give her a night's lodging.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I have invited her with her brother to supper this night.
Will you —

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: O it's Friday, and I know you have flesh.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Thou wouldst take her any night. Is she not flesh?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Sweet cousin, I would not eat her. If you please to commend me to her: let me see, for what — I leave that to you.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Go in, let me alone. This petulant fool.
Shall be my scaffold to erect my plots.
Come, friends, unload your sorrows on my heart.
Griefs weight is eased; when each one bears his part.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: Thus am I stolen out from the convent. Abbot,
Lie there, thou happy warranted case
Of any villain. Thou'st been my stalking-horse,
Now these ten months. So long 'tis since the abbot
Went on a solemn pilgrimage and left
My brother, a good honest friar, his friend
Deputed for him. But my brother scarce
Warm in his new vice-honour, walking out
To visit me one morning, at my house
Fell dead of an impostume suddenly.
I buried him in private; but from's blood
Am purer than the crystal. Studying now,
How to turn sorrow into policy,
I have assumed his shape. Who can deny,
But that a dunce may rise to dignity?
Blind ignorance doth not always strut in satin.
It often walks a clergy pace in black,
And deals the holy rites with as bold hands,
As if it grasped Jove's thunder: and did judge it
Enough to stare, look big, and with a brow
More rugged than is Radamanth's, denounce
Torrors against ill deeds: the whiles their own
Are not less monstrous, but less broadly shown.
Thus in myself, how easie't is, I prove,
To sweat out judgements 'gainst the sins we love.
As if a garment of world-cozening grace
Were impudently good, set out by place.
Well, I get nothing by this borrowed form,
But countenance to my thefts. This hollow tree
Keeps all my holiness: lie there abbot, till
My work is done, then do thou hide my ill.
Mass here's comes one already.

sp.speaker: Valent.
sp.p: Now have I, like a parasite, covered my back with brains. Out of my usurer's gouty toe, I have spun a fair suit. I would fain hear, whether the devil be dead or no. Yet I need not be so inquisitive, for I'm sure he has given me nothing in's will. Now am I in quest of some vaulting house. I would fain spend these crowns, as I got them, in coney-catching. I ha'the game in scent, and will follow it with full cry.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Stand — give the word.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Word? what word? am I beleaguered?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Few words are best among friends. Empty your pockets, and you may vault the lighter. Quick.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Thou'rt an honest fellow, a very honest fellow. In good faith I had no great need of money; but since thou hast brought me some, I'll not refuse it.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Troth, I ha' but a little.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Faith nor I. We'll even draw cuts, who shall ha' both.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Agreed. — shall we breathe?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Good fortune grant, you be able to pay me for this pains. In sadness, I deserve double fees.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: I'll make you plead harder, ere you sit down to tell your money.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Look that your case be good, I shall pick a hole in't else.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Well, let the law pass.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not altogether so: lest we be both hang. — stand your ground. Zlid, I cannot abide these running cocks.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: I have seen a runner win the battle. — shall we draw stakes?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ha? A match — throw by weapons, and let's embrace.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: I am a villain, but I fear your clutch worse than a sergeant's

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
As I'm true thief, thou mayst trust me. Ha sirrah!
Robin hood, and the pindar of Wakefield had not a stiffer bout. Shall we cling, like a couple of eels, not to be dissolved but by thunder?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Most liberally. Let's set up shop together.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Done: and to begin our trade, behold a customer. Stand close.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: This russet-shape of a plain-dealing yeoman
Spirits my hopes with boldness. Sharp suspicion
Like to a winking justicer shall see me,
And yet not see me. Thus with grief-swollen eyes,
I'll match my wife, and children's miseries.
This fifty pound I'll husband like a badger;
Buy and sell barley: and so easily wind
Into the present passages of Bedford.
How good a schoolmaster is poverty!
I could not live on hundreds, that came in
By annual rends; now I begin to thrive
On the small fragments. Thus like prodigals,
That once did scorn the meat, now glad of pottage.
The manor gone, I'll try to live oth' cottage.
Bedford, ha' for you.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Stand. Give the word.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: The word, you're a thief.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You might ha' shot twice, and not hit it righter.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: What do you shoot at?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: O sir, like your Jesuit, all at the purse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Will you cast out the devil, and save's a conjuring.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Are you so cunning at the black art? I'll try your skill. What, both at once? that's no fair play.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Fair play is for fencers. Yet thou seemst a good fellow. Thou shalt have it. Stand aside, partner.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Sayest thou me so, boy? than there's money, win't and wear't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Now could I get in and rob 'em both — Hercules! He lays about him like Orlando Furioso, or a coward turned desperate. Brave boy i'faith. We might ha' robbed two and twenty taffeta-cloaked roarers, before this freese-jacket. O, your surly boar is like
a bloodied mastiff: when your spruce pantaloon bawls like a whelp in a tavern: yet at the sight of cold iron runs, as if he had seen a sergeant.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Hold, hold: keep your cash.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: The money's good money sir, if it be not too heavy for you

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Nay, for the weight I could make shift, but for the scurvy conditions go with it.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Have you any gall to't sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not not so much as pigeon. Put up thy cash my brave quintessence of hobbinolls. Give me thy hand. How many thousand cudgels hast thou broken i' thy days about a maypole?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: I warrant, as many as would make all Bedford chimney's smoke a whole winter.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Jest on. Have you any more to say to me.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Nothing my brave Clem of th' Clough, but I would thou wouldst deal with us. Say, shall we put all our stocks together, and set out a ship of our own?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Ha? first tell me truly what you are.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Agreed. Let's sit down to counsel. I am the abbot of Newnham.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: How? much?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: I'll not bate you an ace on't, till the old abbot returns from pilgrimage. My chamber shall be our rendezvous. The devil himself in the shape of a blurting constable will not look for us there.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I am a soldier, and in this vacation time am forced to do like lawyers; when suits do not make them, they make suits: because the wars will not maintain me, I maintain the wars. I set up my bills in Bedford here, for a physician, and dealt with gripe for the gout. I have a project to swell our purses till they burst. Will you second me?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: As inseparably, as a condition does an obligation.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I have often heard the gripulous dotard talk of fairies: and how rich the house proves that they haunt. I have ripened the blister of his imagination to the full. Shall we lance it? I have keys that shall secure our conveyance. Is't a match?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: The safest stratagem we could devise,
By craft, more than by strength, all thieves do rise.
Of many politic knaves you cannot spy one.
The fox will have his prey before the lion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Two or three nights we'll scatter some small pieces of silver, till opportunity plump our project.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: I take it rightly. O 'tis quick and sharp.
So with a gudgeon lost, we'll catch a carpe. A booty.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: As I was saying, master Bromley, why should you take th' advantage of your neighbour Sager here? Y' have got the reversion of his lease. There's is but one life to come in't. We are all mortal. It may come ere you look for't. I love peace, I love peace.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: I say, that life is forfeit: and I'll enter on all. The law is on my side. I'll not be bound to th' peace.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: Nay sir, I'll bind no man: but if I could persuade you — to be fleeced both, so I might be kept warm in your wool — how say you neighbour Sager?

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: Alas sir, I do but defend my own.
Nay could be well-contented to sit down
With some (Though unjust) loss. I judge it best.
Though with some prejudice to buy my rest.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: Therein you wrong yourself: the law is impartial, like a bell, as sound on one side, as on th' other, if the clapper be right. Master Bromley a word — what will you judge me worthy of, if I persuade him to relinquish his right? You know your case —.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Here's twenty angels: work it good master Griffin, work it; and you shall be my everlasting attorney. But if you fail, you must return.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: Pish, never talk of that man — Mr. Sager, a word — I love peace, though I cannot live by't. I respect my conscience above my purse — when to has no money in't. — what will you give me to draw Bromley to a good handsome composition?

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: Not a penny, till y' have done't.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: You know 'twill go against you, but I love peace.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: (I never knew't in any of your tribe.
Th' event be what it will, I'll give no bribe.)
Sir, as I like your end — God and my cause,
Are coat of steel, 'gainst the sharp fangs of laws.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Shall we walk on? our journey's long.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Not so long as you take't. Stand, good Mr. lawyer, shall I put a case to you now?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Come, untruss, we have haste of business?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Quick sirrah, I shall serve an execution of your throat else

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Indeed gentlemen, I am sorry that I'm not better stored for you. If you had taken me coming from term, I could have served your turns better.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Bind them, hamper the rogues. Serve a habeas corpus on that fieri fancies.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: How happy were this common wealth! how sound!
If every corrupt lawyer's fingers were thus bound.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Sager, I know thee poor: here take thy purse.
Though I rob these, no poor man shall me curse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Tarry till I lay the lawyer in the midst of his clients.
Are your talons bound harpy? Thou liest now like a stallion new gelt, betwixt two mares. This is a distringis sirrah.
Farewell pettfogger.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: O neighbours, I'm undone, undone.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Then help to undo me. I'll have my action against the rogues.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: Stay till you catch them master Bromley.
Well, somewhat this my falling state relieves:
That honesty speeds well even amongst thieves

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Help, help. Good master Griffin, your breath's strongest, yawl, yawl. Your tongue could never stand your clients in more stead.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I heard this way some man's distressed voice,
Crying for help: some robbery. O 'tis no wonder!
A thief and bawdy house are never far asunder.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: O good woman help, help to untie us.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: I know 'em all. Two knaves, one honest man.
They know not me in this translation.
Come sir, I'll lose you first, help you the rest.
Do well to all, but to the good do best.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: O that I had the villains upon an execution now.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Would you turn hangman, sir?

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: i'faith sweet wench, I would show 'em the law.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O pity them: necessity has no law.
Perhaps want forced them; though it was not good.
What horseleeches are they, that full, suck blood!
There is an inn, enter, refresh yourselves.
Their loss is money, yet I moan their state.
Who pities me most, most unfortunate!
Robbed of a husband's love, now of himself.
How far is this beyond all loss of pelf!
He sold me hither; may that sinful price
Of my deep sorrow never prejudice
His happiness, what climate ever holds him.
Be blessed, sweet husband; let my ruin buy
Thy wished content, though I forsaken die.
This witch has tired me with her customers,
Whom I have all sent home with bettered minds.
Against her vicious will, I force her strive
By virtue rather, then by lust to thrive.
I know, I am expected.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: The jacks be now uncaged, and fluttered hence.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: (The woman, that released them, I should know.
She frees them from this bondage to a worse.
There is no thief, like whore, to pick the purse.)

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Shall we not shift ground?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: By no means. A thieves safest residence is in the same plat he did the robbery. There, of all places, the cuckoldly hue will never cry after him.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: When shall we share the booties, and be proud,
How liberally our division mounts?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: The day's work done, we'll cast up the accounts.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Where's the pettifoggers portmanteau?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Lay't there. So, you shall see me catch a fat pickerel, with this gudgeon presently. Stand close.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Uncle, uncle, I had a certain scurvy dream tonight .

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Dream? what of dreams? good cousin be not so nice.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I dreamt —

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Be hanged.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Be you hanged, uncle.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Behanged both, except I may have some drink.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: methought I found a great deal of money.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I would we had it, cousin, without dreaming.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Whoop master — no part of my finding.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No matter for a part: all's mine.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nay, all's mine for dreaming.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Nay, all's mine for finding: and I'll keep't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Soft, sirrah: it lies there for a wager.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What wager, sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Marry, that whoever finds it, shall lose all the money in's purse.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I'll not meddle with it.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I'll ha' no part in't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Judgement, gentlemen: ha' they not lost the wager?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Vast. Lost, lost; as sure as virginity; no sooner laid than lost.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Come then to pay, to pay. (Sure this is gripe, my bedford-gouty-ua. Plague o' ▪ your stilts; what carpenter set 'em upright? not my wimble, I hope.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O I am spoilt, spoilt; this 'tis to dream of finding money — I knew, what 'twould come to.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Save your labour, good master thief: for my breeches are ith' fashion, a great deal of pocket, but no lining.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: This is the rock that split me. O good fate!
That thou hadst now about thee half my state.
Is't sin to rob the thief? by usurious course,
He once robbed me, now I rob him by force.
No difference but this, twixt him and me.
I ha' not such protection, as had he.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: O I am a poor man, a very poor man.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Thou art indeed; wealth without use doth free
No soul from the bleak storms of poverty.
Who cannot nature's requests satisfy
Out of his wealth, his coffer's rich, not he.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Be they all bound to the good forbearance?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Thus far quits my revenge. The usurer lies,
As fast in mine, as I am in his ties.
Now let me kill him. No, blood shall not die
my other sins in purple. Lie there. Lo!
That the wise law would serve all usurers so.
How few in thy bonds didst thou ere untie?
Now bound thyself, so without mercy lie.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Come, let's retire to our refuge.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Uncle, uncle. I would this all were but a dream too.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: O coz, I am damned, damned, my money's gone.
Elstow mortgage is lost. Wallow to me, nice.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O uncle, it's dangerous tumbling, snakes i' the grass.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Wallow to me, thirsty.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Master, I'm so dry, I cannot stir my feet.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Help. —

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: More robberies yet? 'tis strange, how villains swarm!
Mischiefs hold close to keep each other warm.
Three rank corruptions make their near abode.
An abbey, bawdy-house, and a thievish road.
Where be these men distressed? — how? my usurer?
Shall I unbind him, that hath bound my husband
In merciless fetters? Yes, I'm bidden, still;
With good deeds to requite my enemies ill.
Come, devil, I'll unlose thee.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: O how I'm crossed!
My money, and my mortgage, all, all lost.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Mass, a pretty wench — if she lay thus bound before me, I would not lose her, but upon some conditions.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Will you go in sir, and refresh yourself?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I'll follow thee, sweet girl. Would I could cope this mortgage, though my other be passed hope.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Do they brew wine here?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: See how this woman still me quits, and crosses.
I rob and bind, and she relieves their losses.
Why doth she thus? It's but a trick of hers:
By charity to draw in customers.
I am now patient, but more cuckold still.
I help her to supply, 'gainst my own will.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Shall we retire to my chamber, and share?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Tarry. Here comes another jackdaw: let's pluck him, and take his feathers with us — stand.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Thou durst not say so, were we on just terms.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: You should be some lawyer, you stand so on your terms
Faith, we must change professions with you, you must give's our fees.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: You'll earn them first?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Brave sir, so do not lawyers always.
But when you're paid yourself, you'll give's our due.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Hold, gentlemen, this is my friend.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Thine, noble Valois? thou shalt beg his ransom then.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: He stands secure. Haste to your chamber. There I'll meet you presently, and then we'll share.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Are thy ends good in this given liberty?
Or dost it here alone to murder me?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Not with my sword, but with a tale shall wound thy amazed heart — come, let's sit down.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: What tale? good friend, be plain and short.
Woe to a heart, by expectation centuples the smart.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: I have commendations to you from one vaster: for by's description you should be the man.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Lives vaster then?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Alas sir, you know he's dead.
And by your bloody hand was murdered.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: By me?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Is not your name sir Benjamin gripe!

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: You killed him, sir. Poor man he died
With penitence to heaven, to you remission.
Said, that you did it like a man, provoked
By his intemperate rage. Fate gave that I
Keeping his walk, came to close up his eye.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Heaven pardon me. What said the dying vaster?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: He charged me seek you out, and gave me gold,
To bury him in secret; lest his death
Should hazard yours, and charmed my silent breath.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: His love gives fire to my green pile of sorrows.
May his bones rest in peace: in grief I live;
Less he and heaven do my black fault forgive.

sp.speaker: Vaster.
sp.l: He hath forgiven you, only this he begs;
That to the scattered pieces of himself,
Left to survive his miseries uncomplete,
His widow and his orphans, you would yield
Some pity for your own, heavens, and his sake:
And teach that hand, (From which he hoped some good)
To succour theirs, that took away his blood.
He bade me tell you, now all means were gone,
To expiate that sin, save only one:
To hold those up, that on the world's sea swim:
Since he had them undone, you undone him.
That you would be to them, as he should be:
This he bequeathed you as a legacy.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I'll be a just executor of his will.
Good friend, great thanks: my purse thou'st spared to ceaz
But what is worse, haste robbed me of my peace.
Vaster, thou'rt dead: if thy transformed soul,
Could from the battlements of you high tower,
Behold the vowed endeavours of my heart,
To satisfy thy will and my huge debt,
In thee, to thine, thou wouldst my merit set
'Mongst thy best friends: yet narrow are my bounds;
To give them plasters, that first gave them wounds.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Farewell sir, think on vaster.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Friend adieu. To vaster and my vow I will be true.
How thick the sharp pulse of my conscience bears!
How strangely my distracted fancy threats!
O unappeased murder, that still keeps
The sensitive committer from fast sleeps:
And murmurs in the ears a fatal knell
Of restless thoughts on earth, of worse in hell,
How deep thou strikest me with a silent blow!
Be patient heart, to thy fate humbly bow.
Fetch him again I cannot; o his swoon
Is too too mortal. Why then hurled I down
My sinking spirits? Let me sly to mirth,
And burden cares with wine, to make them sink.
The world's rule is, who feels the load of conscience let him drink.
But o importunate grief! too hard it is,
To counterfeit a false and forged bliss!
Yet once I'll force a trial; I have here an inn,
I hear and wonder, is turned house of sin.
I'll see, if the loose sprawls, with their sharp wit,
Can give my mind a medicine for this fit.
Whores I abhor, as gardiner's jays: no matter;
Once for experiment, I'll hear them chatter.
sp.p: Prevention! I think here's one of the journey-women come, to proffer me her service. Black prostitution! that any such face should ever wait upon thee. Sister, what seek you?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What is hard to find:
An honest man, or else my eyes are blind.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Fut, if I say I'm one, I then fall short,
Of the occasion I intend for sport.
I'm such a fool in this priapus-rode.
sp.p: methinks , sweetheart, your honestman should be one, that should please your appetite, stir your veins, tickle your blood, and make you laugh delight into your panting spleen.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: An honest devil.
They're friends to hell, that tempt weak souls to evil.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Come, let me kiss thee — so: this was with ease;
Words are airy shades, they're deeds that please.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir, do not think to enter my chaste fort,
Encouraged by this parley. You presume —

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Not to unlock thy treasures with such keys.
Gold only can surprise such holds as these.
And I have that will do 't.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Then use it well.
How's wealth abused, when it conducts to hell!
Sir, I will set no price on your desires.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: I'll be the franker paymaster.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You must: then pay me for my virtue: so I'll ▪ take it.
What starves lust, is well bought; not what it feeds.
'Tis folly's dregs, with coin to buy ill deeds.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Come, come; why should you be so quaint, and nice,
That know what belongs to't ? ' dsso, a virgin
At thirteen, or perhaps a little under,
Could not with whewling nay's be so perverse,
In her beworded maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I must.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Thou dost not rightly of my merits deem.
I would not know you such, as you now seem.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: The golden footed law, that goes or runs,
Stays, and turns back, as we give motion to it,
Shall step the pace, which thou wouldst have it. Nay,
Speak as thy tongue instructs it. I will change
Thy poverty to gold, rich robes, a coach,
And prancing coursers, that shall whirl thee through
The popular streets; and when thou sittest in pride,
The tamed law shall lackey by thy side.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: These are some incitations to a heart
Tainted with malice, or that thinks a heaven
In glorious ostentation; or would stand
Affected with the bane of prurient lust.
I'm of another temper. Pray you leave me.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Thou shalt nectar drink:
Make ebrious waste of the sweet Gnossian wines;
Pheasants shall be course diet: refined marrow,
Small pounded nuts, and lozenged amylum,
Scraped pearl and date-stones sprinkled on each slice,
And strewed with sugar, like white frost on ice.
Grant me but love, I'll rain a shower of gold
Into thy lap, outshining Jove, when he
Wrapped in his glory courted Danae.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Thy language does affright me. O my stars!

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: O let not tears spoil such a beauty. Tell me; why spill you water like a crocodile, to captive me; that might have don't with mirth, nimbler than air?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sir, I have no desire,
To take your lust, but pity. Some what prompts my credulous heart, there is some goodness in you.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: My truth shall quite thy faith, impart thy mind.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I'll trust you, sir. I am a wretched woman,
The widow or the wife, I know not whether, of the distressed or dead vaster.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: How? I faint to tell thee; thou art then a widow:
The wars have ended his infortunate days.
Nay, let not grief oppress thy spirits. O,
I have killed the wife and husband with one blow.
Lift up thy swooning eyes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O let me die. Rather short death, than lingering misery.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Revive thy heart: vaster yet lives in me:
I am his son, that hath thy husband's lands.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And can I look for mercy at your hands?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Receive this earnest; all my state is thine.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You cannot with these spells charm me to sin.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I do not: when I taint thy chaster ears
With motions of black lust, pronounce me villain.
Tell me, who brought you to this brothel-inn?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: He, to whom heaven (I trust) hath cleared all sin.
My vaster sold me hither. I was content.
Thus to relieve his state, when all was spent.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: But couldst thou live infectless in this air?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I have, and will.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Will? This gives strange suspicion.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I made a promise, that without consent
Of her that bought me, I would not depart.
See where th' enchantress comes.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Now minion, you must be gadding. Cry you mercy, landlord: if you'll have any sport, walk in, walk in. You shall take out your rent here, landlord. She shall be your own vacation and term too, landlord.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: So, you pernicious dam of lusts foul litter,
You that buy beauty and do sell 't again;
and live by th'occupation. Hear you? Free
This woman from your brothel slavery.
Or I shall bring you to the cart and lash.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: O I am cast away; she cost me fifty pounds, I never got four groats by her yet.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Thou shalt lose more by keeping her. Go cleanse the house from this disorder, or I here discharge thee.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Good landlord, bestow her where you will. I am content to be rid of her, so I may hold your favour —
sp.l: Fox pull your honesty. Is this the dancing maid?
One more such purchase will undo my trade.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Hostess, Ostice, where's your kinswoman?

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Yonder sir, talking with my landlord, your worship's son.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Son Benjamin? yea faith, are you so close with a wench? Come hither — she's a whore, take heed on her.
sp.l: If she want men's, bring her home: she shall keep my house.
Faith, I grow old, and cannot now long live:
O such a wench would be restorative
Persuade her Ben

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I'll do my best, sir ▪ see,
The pleased fates consent to succour thee.
My father's house shall shelter thee unknown.
Please the old man with words, but hold your own.
If my plot takes, as I can hope no less,
This lust of his shall thy good fortunes bless.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Come, sister to my sorrows, and myself.
They say, society in woes doth lighten
Our pressures; but I find the contrary.
My woes are heavier by thy company
My grief for thy distress, doubles mine own.
I should be far less wretched, if alone.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Sweet brother. since we must both suffer, think it some comfort, that we share an equal fortune.
sp.l: Grief has less power to work on our sad hearts;
Where mutual loves contend to bear their parts.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Little once thought thy mother, that thy fate
Should stoop to service to relieve thy state:
We are not tried, but in our misery.
He is a cunning coachman that can turn
Well in a narrow room. To manage plenty
In a right form, commends the state, not person.
He's blessed, that to be rich can give consent
With honesty, or rest poor with content.
I wonder, Benjamin doth not visit us.
His last relief is done, if that spring dry,
We faint for succour, and must fainting die.
sp.p: See, here comes Bromley, once our father's steward: sure, he'll support us. Sister, cry his kindness: thy speech is more pathetical.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Thieves, lawyers, rogues, harlots, and innkeepers, are men's purgations. Griffin has cheated me: took twenty angels from me; thieves took 'em from him. He promised to draw Sager to compound; now the day's gone against me.
sp.l: O I could wish my nails turned vultures talons,
That I might tear their flesh in mammocks, raise
My losses from their carcases turned mummy.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Good sir, a word —

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Now Kitlin, what would you have?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Sir, remember we are the miserable children of lost Vaster; whom once you served.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: What's that to me?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: I hope, sir, you can spare somewhat to us distressed.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: This is plain begging. Minion, fall to work,
And earn supply to wants with diligent labour.
For Vaster's sake I will not urge the statute.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: The statute, Judas? w' are no beggars, though
We tried thy courtesy. Cursed be thy fate,
Thou from our father got'st thy whole estate.
sp.p: Yet grudgest us some fragments. Hence, out dog: if thou stayest miscreant —

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Boy, I'll smoke you for't.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Do thy worst, devil. An insatiate worm strike deep into thy conscience, sile thy heart strings with rubbing frets: and turn thy derogated name,
sp.l: On foggy blastings of eternal shame.
Ingratitude is gone; and in his room,
Extortion and a fiend is hither come.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I'm going to see my mortgage —

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Good sir, show mercy on two wretched orphans.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Out beggars, mercy? what dost talk to me of mercy? I'm going to let my grounds. I have no leisure for mercy.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Go thou accursed Cain: in misery,
When thou beg'st mercy, be't as far from thee.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Sir, y' have undone our parents; pity us.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I cannot stay to hear you, I have business.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Heaven be as deaf to thee, when thy soul breath
Shall beg some respite at thy violent death.
This fellow sure will succour us.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: June, July, August, September — the first day —

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Sir, raise our prostrate fortunes with some help: some little help, you know us.

sp.speaker: N●c.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I remember I have seen you. Let's see — the fourteenth day — bad. I must do no deed of charity today; I have precedent for it. 't is lost.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Now I remember, when I went to school,
I read of one Vespasian a good emperor,
That told his courtiers if a day out-slip him,
Wherein he did nor good, that day was lost.
The next he would redeem't with double cost.
Ill coloured sin, how shameful dost thou look,
In them that plead thy warrant from their book!

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Fourteenth day. A good turn forgotten. O here's learning from the stars.
sp.l: Though I do little good ere I am rotten,
Like citizens, I would not have't forgotten.
Yet let me study on't: though a man may not give, he
May buy, I hope without danger. Fair sister,
What shall I give you for your maidenhead?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Thus much: a broken head.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: O — o — forgive me, good Calender — I perceive now, thy counsel's true. It's an evil day indeed: I should neither have bought nor sold on't.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Hence, sky-consulting Gipsy: men commit
Sins dark as night, and blame the stars for it.
Another passenger — o this is Sager.
His wife was once a servant to our mother.
Alas, when these built from our ruinous woe
Relieve us not, what should this poor man do.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: I long to hear from London; how my suit
Ends, or depends: if lost, I'm lost with it.
Who would trust any bars this tottering world
Can plot to fortify our wheeling states!
When the strong doors of justice may be broke,
Or lifted from the hinges by the force
Of politic engines: or the safest lock
Be picked with a false key.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sir, dwells there any mercy in your heart?

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: Yes: or of mercy, I must hope no part.
I know you, and your wants. My wife was once your parents servant.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: True, but that time is past,
And in her service now I would be placed.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: That were too lavish yielding to your woe.
I am but poor, troubles have made me so,
Yet of that small life-blood, which my drencht state
Has left it by the law's sharp surgery,
Embrace a portion, as your needs require;
And I may give. Here comes your enemy's son.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I have been seeking all you three with news.
Good news; friend Sager, the day's yours.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: It's welcome. I have the better means to succour these.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: You have prevented my request: I purposed
To beg that kindness of you. Robin, I would
Entreat you to accept my service, but
I mean the name of it: for in deed I'll use thee
As my most equal and respected friend.
Nan, in thine arms I throw and lock myself;
My fortunes be all thine: the key's thy love;
Let this kiss be the seal. Ye sacred powers
Make indissoluble this knot of ours.
Now, master Sager, give her that respect,
You would my wife: all charges are my debt.
sp.p: Robin, you know the house; conduct your sister thither; that done, convey these letters to the widow sorrow; (That's her borrowed name) she lies at my fathers.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: With just hands.
I'm prouder of thy love, then of thy lands.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: O pure quintessence of thy profession.
How many hast thou robbed, thus to make up
Thy perfect goodness! as if wiser nature
Had made an extract of ten thousand lawyers,
And thrice refined it with immortal fires:
Then set it like a sanctified lamp
On th' altar of thy soul; to give exemplar light,
In the dull darkness of this sin-born night.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Bromley's grown mad with rage: I'm jealous of him. You know the hopes of your posterity dwell on your present fortunes: all which burn with the short taper of your singular life, say he should quench it.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: How sir? murder me?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I cannot tell, it's but my jealousy.
'Tis not amiss, to keep preventions eye
Open and wary. Instruments of death
Stand ready pressed to a malicious arm.
And policy, like a cunning Jesuit,
Watches behind that arras for a call.
The deed once done, help it who can, or shall.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: What ground for this suspicion find your thoughts?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: The fury of his madness, envys some,
That surges from the poisoned avarice
Of his swollen heart: his broken resolutions,
Wherein his traitor-tongue can scarce forbear
The protestation. Give me leave to fear.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: What will you counsel me?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: That must be studied. Thus — listen — we'll try what mischiefs he can warp: with wooden wasters learn to play at sharp.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: O my back, my back —

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: How do you, sir?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: O son, son, worse than ever. The gout was but a stitch to this. O the colic, the colic and stone.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: There be two of them master, ask the widow else.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Sure it will rend my bowels out.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: It's just: the stone ith' bladder now should make him smart that has so long been sick of stone ith' heart.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: O that I knew where my old physician lived.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Keep on your habit. Our walk's turned Paul's, I think.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Zlid, if our third party were here, we would venture on 'em all. They're but Welsh freeze; they would shrink at the sense of iron.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Let's muffle up our villains with the shadow
Of some great conference: if a cheat be offered,
We'll not refuse: but now to compass it,
Must not be done by force of arms, but wit.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Son Benjamin, you must to Goldington,
To view young Bruster's lands: they're offered me
This morn in mortgage. Hark you —

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Thirsty, come hither.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Ha'you any drink there?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No; but come drink thyself drunk with poetry.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Faith, poetry now a day's will scarce make a man drink. I had as lief be a pot as a poet: then I should sometimes be full of good liquor.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O, your poet is too full of that, it makes him thread bare. Sirrah, I ha' made a sonnet here to my mistress; she ne'er wrought such a one on her sampler. Lay thine ear close to my musical tongue, I shall ravish her.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: You shall be hanged for't then.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: Open thine ears, like an oyster a sunning
Even as the bird, which we chameleon call, doth live on air for aye:
So my kind heart, ever like a stock-dove shall feed on thy love all day.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Ay, and all night too.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Ay, and all night too: but that night would make the verse too long. Now I talk of night, let me see what time of day it is. I have business, must not be rhymed away.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Pray y' sir, how speaks your watch? One? mine lies inclining to two you have a pretty interpreter of the time there. Who made it, French or Dutch? You need not doubt me, sir, I am the new parson of saint Peter's in Bedford.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Sir, then as I may say, have joy in your new benefice, for bellypiece you must ha' none. Pray let's peruse your watch, see you mine.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Fezz 'Sir, y' have a brave wash there. Chill warrant the King's wash-maker made it. Beseech you master nice, let me see master parson wash. Master parson will you sell your wash, Chill give you good cash for it.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: No, my honest friend, I will not sell it.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Will you run with me for it?

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Run? no.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Chevore ye run for't, you shall ne'er have't else.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: O my watch — Nic. O my watch.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Stop the thief, stop the thief.
sp.stage: Vaster runs away with curfews watch: curfew with Nices.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Stop the priest, stop the priest.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Let him go, he runs for a wager.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: How now? is my cousin nice playing at base?
I know one of them well, by his sad tale
Of Vaster's death: for that I'll not pursue him.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Son, I did rest me, hoping to go forward.
But so increase my pains, I am not able.
Survey you Bruster's lands, and speed return.
All's for your good, for I am now outworn.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I go sir — all's for me; yet while she lives,
And his hydropic spirits can look through
His body's loopholes, and convey the pleasure
Of his contemplate gold, his lusts sole God,
Through those windows to th' admiring heart:
Nothing comes from him; not the superfluities
Of base's things, not being first improved.
I am his only issue, and on me
I think he means to settle all his state.
It's the only way to give me cursed and poor,
To build my nest on such extorted store.
Those fathers, that distressed men's ruins use,
"As scaffolds to build up their racked wealth,
" prove in the end, like city-houses, that
"On small foundations carry spacious roofs:
" when the incensed heavens in tempests frown,
"Their own top-heavy weight tumbles them down.
" the first or second generation spills
"By riot, what by wrong the father fills.
In this I'll be a mirror to these times:
And by the hand of charity return
To every man, what by his covetous rape
Their states are ravished of: so work my rest.
Th'ill gotten gone, that which remains is blessed.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: O thirsty, honest thirsty. Thy old master is but a dead man. I cannot piss man: my urine's stopped.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: You should drink, hard, master: all this comes with pinching yourself of your liquor. This is the reason, that so few Dutchmen are troubled with the stone. Your miserable churl dribbles like the pissing conduit: but his jovial son with a stream like ware-water-spout. This is the cause, the usurer falling sick, so seldom rises by the staff of physic: for he has no water for the physician to cast.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Now the gout, dropsy, lethargy take possession of their legs. I ha'lost my wind, and my watch, and I fear, my wench too.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: You have watched fair: sure that parson was some Irishman.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Some hangman uncase him. I ha' bene at the parsons, and he's no such manner of man.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What crew's this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Bless your worship: I am your worship's sons tenant. I ha' brought a rogue to your worship, to be examined.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What fault hath has he committed? Clarke, to your office: take his examination. Now neighbour sleepy, are you constable?

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: A good harmless constable, a thief may take him napping.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: An't please your worship, the rude ragamuffin comes into my house, calls for drink; and when the tapster came with a reckoning, he broke the pot about's head; because he had not a clean apron on.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, because he misreckoned me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Whose fault was it, to wipe out the score?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not mine. Indeed I anointed the score with butter, and the tapsters own dog licked it out.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Uncle, uncle, as sure as my watch is lost, this is master Valentine the physician.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: O coz, that it were true. Pray sir, let me move a question.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You may command my answer sir, you're a justice.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Were not you the man, that healed me of the gout?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Troth sir, I have done so many cures, that I forget a number of my patients. Th'other day I cured a lunatic
cobbler, pitifully run out at soul, when he was given o'er by the physicians. I let him blood, took three hen-eggs, sucked 'em out, into the shells I put his blood, set them under a brood-goose. When she had hatched the rest, I gave these three putrified eggs to a dog: the dog grew mad, the cobbler sober. And now my memory runs back, I call to mind one of Bedford, sick of the gout, whom I cured.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I am the man, my renowned paracelsian: thou shalt have the other 25. pound. Constable, I discharge you. Ostice, I'll see you paid: set your reckoning on my score: trouble me no further: leave us, leave us. Now my deep diver into the secrets of nature, I have a cure for thee, more desperate than the former.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What is't sir, that my art cannot extend to?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: The stone, the stone: I am pitifully gripped with the stone, I ha'lost my pissing.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, the disease is somewhat dangerous.
Yet if that your expulsive faculty
Retain true force, I'll warrant to make you piss.
I must awhile withdraw to study sir. —
Now am I puzzled: blood, what medicine
Should I devise to do't? It must be violent.
Give him some aquafortis; that would speed him.
Let's see. Methinks — a little gunpowder
Should have some strange relation to this fit.
I have seen gunpowder oft drive out stones
From forts and castle-walls, huger than he
Has any in his reins or bladder, sure.
Faith, 'cause I am a soldier, I'll make trial
Of that same black and vaporous mineral.
I'll shoot into his belly: if the gun hold,
I ▪ le give him charge enough: some aquavitae
First brewed together would allay it well.
I'll swear to try it, if I do not miss,
By a strange trick I'll make my usurer piss.
Sir, I'll go in and prepare for aou.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p:
Do so. Here, thirsty, there be the keys of the buttery:
attend upon him good thirsty: let him lack nothing, as thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: I love you master, but here's a good key I love better. Sweet instrument of my joy, let me kiss thee. Alas, that thou and I should be such strangers. We ha' but one barrel: now if that should be in my master's disease, troubled with the strangullion, and could not run — well, if it be not empty, I'll give't a scouring.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Now if this rare wonder of leeches can cure me of this griping, that I may have some forty or threescore years more to gather in, by that time I shall gather enough to keep me all the rest of my life. When a man grows up to to six or seven score, it is high time to think of mortality, and to take some ease. These three or four nights I ha' been haunted with fairies: they dance about my bedside, pop in a piece of gold between the sheets, scatter here and there fragments of silver, in every corner. I keep my chamber swept, clean linen, fire to warm them every night. I was at first afraid , they had been spirits; now I see, they are good harmless fairies. If I can please them, I shall grow rich, rich.
Son I have stayed for you.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: You have done your health the more wrong, sir.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: How dost like my mortgage?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: It's a fair living, sir; but I would not have you meddle with it.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Why, my wise son?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: O sir, good deeds are scant,
When we advantage take of poor men's want.
sp.p: Bruster's an honest man; lend him some money without such sharp security.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Not a doit. If he come to me, and convey the mortgage I have it ready; else I have no money.
Son come and sup with me.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I follow, sir. Preposterous transversion of ourselves!
Th'erection of our faces should instruct
Our groveling thoughts to ascend. How do men thwart
The teaching hand of nature, and our birth!
Our heads cut air, and yet our hearts blow earth:
I look for Sager here. He's come.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: Here's my own case and counterfeit; by this dangerless plummet, we may sound the depth of his more close and intricate stratagems.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: So wiser masters lay some easy baits,
At once to tempt and try their servant's truth.
The subject for quack-salving empirics
To exercise their inexperience on,
Should not be men, but malkins.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: Do you think, that he would do me violence asleep? would he not wake me to some conference?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: No, he's a most rank coward; and I know,
Dares not come near thee, though thou wert asleep.
If he does ought, he'll do't by that long engine.
Conceal yourself awhile. How fares my name?
How does she brook my slow-paced coming to her?

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: Faith, in your constancy lightens all grief.
She never hears you mentioned, but she startles:
As if your name like some celestial fire
Quickened her slow-paced spirits with new life.
I never knew virtue and beauty meet
In a more happy mixture. I remove.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I love her freely: she's to me as th'air.
Her beauty is best and blessed, whose soul is fair.
The wolf is come.
sp.stage: Enter Bromley with a fowling piece.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Good evening to you sir.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: My wish requite you.
You walk to have a shoot, sir: I depart.
I would be loath to prejudice your sport.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Saw you not Mr. Sager, sir, of late? This is his walk: I would fain speak with him.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Why would you speak with him?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Sir, for no harm.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I do not think you mean it; but you know, he's valiant like a lion: if cross words should stir your bloods to quarrel — sir, take heed. He'll be too hard for you, and your long weapon. This meadow is his evening walk. Farewell to you sir.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: Good night m. Benjamin; you need not doubt me.
If I could meet him at th' advantage now,
He is the fowl I'd shoot at. His life done,
The farm is mine. O ye, whose hopes depend,
Like lingring shadows, on another's end,
What need you wait with patience nature's leisure,
When such an engine can soon work your pleasure?
Tarry: yonder's a man — now by his habit
It should be Sager. What? and fast asleep?
Wished opportunity to my revenge.
I'll kill him ere he wakes. Stay, grant he should
In this unbeaten meadow lately act
Some horrid sin, please his adulterous lust:
I should then with his body strike his soul,
And sink them both together. Reason no further
Thou chiding conscience. See, the fates have placed
Him sit for vengeance: enemy, sleep thy last.
He's planet-struck, fallen down: now to my farm.
He that would rise, must thank his wit or arm.
O but my murder! pish, whoever stood
In fortune's height, without some touch of blood?
sp.stage: Enter Benjamin and Sager at several ways.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: This I divined.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: Happy prevention!

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Go, thou despairing wretch, and for thy will,
Ten thousand swords shall thy vexed conscience kill.
'T was a vain blow to us, and no blood spilt,
Not less in thy intention is thy guilt.
This clergy-habit which you have assumed,
Make good a while for your supposed death;
Allow his tyranny free scope: live close:
Till time shall ripen those events, we strive
To build on this vile ground. Hold, there's my key:
Into my chamber; I sup at my fathers.
What, come again?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: I cannot be at rest: I must needs see,
If this late murdered corpse removed be.
Some gold I have put up in this portmanteau:
If I should be pursued, this may relieve me.
Ay me! the body's gone: sure it's revealed:
Murder from heaven's eye cannot be concealed.
