What shall I do? sit down: lie there, my gold.
sp.stage: Enter nice, and thirsty, on either side, crying so ho.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Holla, cousin Benjamin. So ho ho.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: O ho ho.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: O me, the country's up, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: This fool hath frayed him.
O guilt! how hast thou made
Cowherd of man to fly at his own shade!
Now cousin nice, what holla you for?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: You had need of a bell to ring you in. Your father has stayed supper for you this hour.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Come then, let's walk on — what's here a portmanteau?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O, o, do not touch it: it's venom.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Why my wise cousin? why are you so timorous?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O it lies there for a wager: there be thieves about it. Take heed cousin; I found a portmanteau once, and lost all the money in my purse. Fly, fly —

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Are you gone? Well, I see now, he that will be wise by Calender, shall be a fool by destiny.
sp.l: Sure, this is Bromley's budget, and has gold
Put up for his escape: 'tis so by th'weight.
It falls into my hands most luckily:
For I have need of cash in these occasions.
Yet I'll repay't again: my honesty
Shall be his friend, whose fear was friend to me.
O, in this glass my represented soul
Stands manifest to my impartial eye.
Ye heaven's rain showers of mercy on my sins:
Lest where my pleasure ends my woe begins.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Run faster, ye dull legs of motion,
That time may follow with a swifter pace.
Let wanton epicures wish you cripple-limbs,
Insatiate with the riot of their joys;
And chide the hasty forwardness of day,
That will not dance attendance on their play.
My spirits wrought upon with tedious woes,
Think that each hour lingering and lazy goes.
Impartial fates, how you delude our thoughts!
Guiding events to their determined ends,
Whether our strength with or against contends.
Whether the passenger wake, or sleep his fill,
The wave and wind-moved vessel goes on still.
Patience then heart! they do not valour know,
That weary faint, but who can suffer woe.
Who's this?
sp.stage: Enter Rob. Vaster with the letter.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: By your leave, mistress Sorrow.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Right, thou'st hit my name.
Yet clear of sin, my sorrow has no shame.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I have letters from Mr. Ben Gripe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: They're welcome. (Poor boy how am I undone!
'Tis hard, a mother must not own her son.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sure I should know that face and language too.
A chill disquiet troubles my soft peace,
And runs like a cold fever through my blood.
I'm very sick of somewhat. O 'tis then
Error, the sickness in all minds of men.
But that I know her absence gives her dead.
I' would swear it was my mother. Alas vain thoughts,
How you would flatter me!

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: — Your provident friend, Benjamin gripe.
Leave out that gripe: it's an unproper name;
Cannot denominate thee for such a creature.
A name can never constitute a nature.
If blessed mankind have a phoenix left;
And vice of that good hath not time bereft;
In this degenerate world's apostasy;
The plural number's lost: that one is he, — son

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Zlid she calls me son.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: That word's o'erslipped.
How easily love is in her language tripped.
Son — of compelling nature not forbears:
Passion must vent itself in speech or tears.
Dost thou not know me?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Yes: this testify.
I beg your blessing on my humbled knee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Rise with heaven's benediction.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Lives my father?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Guess by my grief and silence.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Umh my doubts
Wrap me in further maze. My father dead?
My mother living in his enemy's house?
Let's study. Oft I have heard my father moan,
That this same woman's lust had him undone.
This gives strong faith. Why should she else live here,
But to some such vile end? By heaven 'tis clear.
O that this sap, which my life feeds upon,
Did not confess a derivation
From that corrupted trunk! Well, I will force
Nature run back with a preposterous course.
I'll fashion a forgetful lunacy,
That ere I was her soon. But on my soul,
Not touch her with least hurt. — woman come hither.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Woman! Dear Robin, not thy mother? bless me.
Why dost thou gripe me thus? O some black storm
Is rising on thy brow.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Storm? No, 'tis thunder. Can you read this?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes, I can spell't too well. It speaks my death, dear son —

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Come, come, forget
These filial rights, and nature's attributes.
Prepare yourself to —

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What? O desperate child.
Oft have thy bent knees with a just duty
Kissed the cold earth, to beg my prayers to heaven,
For thy prosperity: oft desired forgiveness
Of thy wild infant-errors. Oft have these
Born thee with soft indulgence: but now, see,
A woeful mother bends her humble knee
To her incensed son; not to conserve
This flesh from death, but thy black soul from hell:
Th' unscaped dungeon, where all parricides dwell.
Think: if thy spirits be not grown mad and wild,
Pity a mother kneeling to her child.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I'm deafer than an usurer to your moans.
I must, like Nero, see the place I bred in.
Be brief in answer: did you never wrong my father's nuptial bed.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Take heed.
Clog not that breast with more sin, that must bleed.
Speak truth and save your soul.
Lie you not here to satiate his lust,
That robbed my father? speak, or you're but dust.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No on my soul.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Now on thy soul thou liest.
Confess, be plain, or without pause thou diest.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Help, heavens or men.
sp.stage: Enter Benia. Valentine, Gripe, nice, thirsty.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: What prodigy's this?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nothing sir, alas nothing: 'twas but my fear.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: It is my servant sir; he meant no ill.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Son, son, howsoever he serves you, I'm sure he does not serve God. Without question, he would have ravished her.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: He would have refreshed her, sir.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Speak widow, is 't not true? — away with him.
Cousin nice, make his mittimus.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: It's not amiss to let him feel some smart.
His life they cannot touch: what his offence
Deserves in heavens, strict justice, mercy pardon.
Parents learn this in tendering children's state:
Too much indulgence is not love but hate.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Sure his complexion doth not give it: let me see your hand, sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Will you feel it, sir?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: (Son offer violence to the mother?) strange!
Till I can sound this mystery of ill,
I'll to the prison and relieve him still.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: You will be gone Mr. Valentine; but I hope you will visit me shortly again.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Before you look for me, sir, — if all fall right,
I vow to visit you again this night.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Ha widow! I am clear of the stone now.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: The less able to do a widow pleasure, sir.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Tut, wench, I mean the disease, the disease.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: (No sir: you have a worse disease behind:)
The body hath no sickness like the mind.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
Try me, sweet. I'm like a leek, though I have
a grey head, I have a green — wilt? wilt be my medicine for the stone? when? when?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: When you have married me I will be your wife.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Pish: first make trial how thou likest me: there is no wit, to marry before experience.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Your house sir, is too public.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Hold, there's the key of my closet. Be thine own pandar for conveyance. I must receive a little money: profit is above pleasure: about ten —

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Good luck direct my hands unto the mortgage.
That found, if or my wit or strength hold tack,
I have a medicine sir, to cool your back.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Alas poor wench: now she's got into my closet, she hugs her hopes, as a politician his airy plot, and cries a prize, a prize. She shall be double coney-catched. Well, it grows fairy-time. O the fine dapper lads, how they frisk about my chamber: when at every step here drops a groat, there a teston. Many drops make a flood. Sure, I'm some wonderful honest man, that they love me thus. I must to bed. Tarry, how then shall I keep touch with the widow? Tha't, I'll sit down in my chair, and feign myself in a slumber. O 'twill be a golden waking dream.
sp.stage: Enter Vaster, Valentine, curfew, like fairies, dancing antics: pinching Gripe, as they pass by him.
sp.p: Oh-oh-thou 'Are angry. Would I were rid of'em . O — sweet spirit — o — do not terrify me thus. What have I done to provoke you?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Confess thy sins. Th' haste some wench in a corner.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I have, I have — o — but I'll not meddle with her.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Whiles thy house was cleanly swept,
And thy conscience chastely kept:
Neat linen, fire and water ready;
And thy purpose good and steady:
whiles thou never sentest the poor
Unrewarded from thy door.
Whiles thou waken'st with the chimes,
Because thou wentest to bed betimes,
We brought thee wealth; but ▪ 'twas in vain:
For now we'll fetch it back again.
Come deliver the keys of your trunks.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: O thieves, you'll rob me, you'll undo me.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: No, gouty blister, well bind thee, undo thee, who will —.

sp.speaker: Val
sp.l: Open thy jaws thou yawning sepulchre:
Here is a morsel for an usurer.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: A piece of cheese of the Low-country dairies.
This is the usual diet of the fairies.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: Now we will rip the lining of thy trunks.
Better the fairies have it then thy punks.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Luck more, than we can carry, hath assigned us.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Each horse his load: we'll leave the rest behind us. Thou greedy panther.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Savage wolf.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Man-eater. Thou setting canker.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Commons' horseleech.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Cheater

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Whose belly has just cause to sue an action
Of trespass, 'gainst thy covetous lust's exaction:
For destiny of many hundred meals,
Which it from others, and thyself too; steals.
The gout.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The dropsy.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: Colic, lunacy,
Like sprites and fairies haunt thy company.
And as thou gapest now, let some bat or owl
Spit backwards i' thy mouth.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: No more. If thou do not
Repent, restore, turn good, sit till thou rot.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What does usury stick in thy teeth? spit out, dog, spit out. Now thou gapest for a mortgage. Dost?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Fare-ill. To those that ask how came this evil, give answer thus: the fairies robbed the devil.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: O — o — oh.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Ho master gripe? what, your chamber door open thus early? how now, bound? gagged? what rogues ha' been here?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Speak to me uncle, speak: the gag's out.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Save the gag. I will hang the whole shire, but I'll find 'em. Jugglers, fairies, incarnal sprites! My money, my heart, my guts, my soul — let me curse myself into the ground, and save a dirge. Run, cry, ride, charge the constables with'em .

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Where be they, sir?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Gone to the devil. Run to a conjurer, cast me a figure.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O, sir, all the conjurers are of their own trade. A mischief on't, I thought there was some scurvy luck towards; the crickets did so cry ith' oven yesterday. And this very hour, as we came in, there was an owl whoo-whooping in the top of the chimney: and just at the threshold, master Bromley here stumbled signs, signs.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Pluck down the signs. I'll undo all the inns in the town: they harbour the thieves.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: You said they were fairies.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Now in sincerity, I heard a great rattling of chains.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: (This makes me wonder! such a robbery, and I not hear it?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Come bridle up this fury. What will you say, if I can produce you the plotter, abettor, or at least accessary to this villainy? What if the picklock can open the chest of all this stratagem?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Alas, poor widow, she was fast, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: No, she was loose I warrant you: how could we have got in, if she had not opened the door? Your cousin nice and I came from a hurly-burly ith' jail. Your son's man has broke from his keeper. And as we were coming, we met this woman very suspiciously stealing out.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: My heart misgave me thus: this devil's tongue
Would work my misdeemed innocence some wrong.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No more words. Cousin, neighbour, take her to the next justice. I must not deal in my own business. Let her be examined soundly, soundly: sent to the jail, roundly, roundly.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: No more. Do not you know, I know you for a whore!
Away with her, I will not hear her speak.
My gold, my silver — o my heart will break.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Come, will you walk? I'll lead, widow, come you next. Master nice, you'll follow.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: As close, as beggary follows drunkenness.
Let me see your hand, widow — o the case is clear.
A yellow spot doth on your hand appear.
Gather up your heels, widow: justice surly dwells hard by.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: How now? my mother guarded? with two rogues?
Sword, thou didst feign to kill her — but — sirrah — you — deliver me this woman, or I'll make thy yellow starched face serve me for a cutwork band.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: O sir, you're well met; you broke from the jail last night. Apprehend him master nice.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I'm somewhat dainty and shy on him, sir. He looks vile sharp on't.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Let him look as sharp, as an apparitors nails, we'll blunt him I warrant ye. Sirrah, I charge you stand.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sirrah, you see I stand charged already. Will you have me run?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: O help, help —

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I ha' not made my will.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: No matter for thy prayers; dispatch it quickly then.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: You'll give me leave, sir, to make my will.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Then my will is — to run away.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Thanks, son; but now do you not, like the lion,
Save the distressed lamb from the wolves paws,
For sacrifice to his own bloody laws?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Dear mother, pardon; be secure —
sp.stage: Enter Bromley, nice, Benjamin, Sager disguised, Anne Vaster.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: This way, this way: here — o have we found you?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: How do these mischiefs flutter in thick heaps!
And cloud my understanding from the light,
I looked the sun should shine, find it dark night
I cannot stand to examine circumstances.
Now master Bromley, whither are you bound?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: Your father gave us charge to have the widow
To master justice Surly's; he suspects her
To have some hand i'th robbery tonight .
Sir it concerns you; he has lost 300. pound.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Umh. My father robbed? the widow charged with it?
Her son unjailed himself? these are harsh turns.
Well, go you two before, prepare the justice.
You have my word for their appearance. Go.
Widow, and robin, now here's none but friends:
You'll give me leave to wonder at these ends.
Of that anon.
Mean time I here present you with a gift,
Dearer to me, then is the sun to earth.
So; narrow up your passions for a space:
Ha'you the mortgage-deeds? give them my hands.
Yet the success on my invention stands.
Mother, and brother, (So I hope your titles)
Myself, and friend here, whom you do not know,
Will bail you both. That done, I have an inn,
Now void of tenant; there dwell all together.
My friendship to the power shall pledge your faith.
Measure good deeds by what man would, not hath.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: What damned fortune's this, that I cannot smell out these thieves? I would sweat them to the gallous, as well as they swore me out of my money. An oath like a strong charm, should conjure their necks into the circle of a rope.
O, here comes my fellow-patient; we both took physic together; purged, purged: but I have a cordial for him. Save you, brother gripe. mr. Bromley, news, good news. It's reported, that Sager's dead.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Dead? I'll go take possession presently.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Do not with too strict rigour exercise your power on his distressed family.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: My time is come, I will not lose an hour.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: It's just, that every man should take his own.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Sir, you speak law, not charity. He that will
Be nothing more than just, is unjust still.
Woe to that quited soul, to whom from heaven
All justice, and no mercy shall be given.
Your mercy to the widow, to the orphans.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: As much as a Puritan has upon a good feast.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Well — let me tell you this — Sager is dead.
So flies report, born on presumptions wings.
But how he died, that airy bird not sings.
Killed — but by whom — weight deeply — I must hence.
The muttring's strong — look to your conscience.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: How's this? killed? — muttering? and conscience? Look, his ghastly melancholy points him out for the murderer. As sure, as a hat-brinks pulled down declares a cuckold, this darkness discovers him.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: I am a villain.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Tell him, that knows it not.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: My narrow heart cannot be capable
Of this huge bulk of sorrow. It must out.
Now, to whose bosom better than my friends?
This hand killed Sager.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: Nay, do your worst.
'Twas but chance medley, accidental slaughter.
Intending with my piece to strike a fowl,
Against my will the cock went down, and he
stood in death's way. It was his destiny.
But Griffin, hark you — let not your tongue stir.
Do not I know you for a forger?
And more — you wot — let not your tongue be loose.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Thus are two foxes catched in one poor noose.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.l: Our guilt shall bind our secrecy; who lives
An unsuspected villain, winks at others
Unlawful deeds, to teach their eyelids how
To wink at his — shall we go to our new hostess?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Where? who?

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: For your where, at the maidenhead, a good likely place. For your who: the widow that old gripe suspects for the robbery; but young gripe hath tenanted to his inn. Mass, she prevents us. Widow, we were coming.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Pray gentlemen walk in; you shall have attendance.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Your company, sweet widow.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I'll not be long from you, sir.
O, some retiring from this house of sin.
Fate! I was never bred to keep an inn.
sp.stage: Enter curfew, Valentine as themselves, Vaster disguised.
sp.l: More customers? that which all inns would see;
Great store of guests: this is a plague to me.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Yonder's mine hostess. Now the water's up, that we cannot get over to the abbey, it is our securest course to commit the money to her custody. If any search should be made, and these tokens found about us, we are all dead men: there's not so much mercy in gripe, as in the plague.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Agreed. Widow, we have some money to pay to a Londoner in Bedford here; and he's not yet come to receive it. Will you lock it up safe for us?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But hear you? Deliver it not to any one of us. Except all three demand it to gether, keep it still.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Help her to bear it in, and see't laid up.
Zlid, my wife takes degrees; she rises fairly.
I sold her hither whore some tricks to do.
Now she's turned whore, and bawd, and hostess too.
Stand close dear wits, and shadow me disguise.
She cast me down, and by her fall I'll rise.
Husbands that love your honour as your life;
Learn now to be revenged, on a false wife.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Your friends expect you sir.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Sweet, I would go.
But here's a charming beauty, that says no.
Will you walk off a little — to the meadow?
I have a tiny business with you, widow?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What is your will, sir? I'm in haste: be short.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: The thing thou wotst on, half a minute's sport.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Forbear, libidinous groom.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Groom? I'm a man.
And can do, hostess, what another can.
Come, shall I speak in gold, and action?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Be damned, enchanter, with thy golden spells.
Thou thinkst, gold can buy lust, when nothing else.
Yet I do love thy soul. Think, think, how dear,
A moment's joy is bought with endless fear.
How ill the flesh steals his unjust delight,
When the soul suffers an eternal night.
Flatter thy glowing hopes with heat no more.
Be not deceived; thy hostess is no whore.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: So: spoke my outside brave; did my rich husk
Allow me impudent; and my undowned chin
Promise my blood unsucked out by this sin,
You would run mad on me.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Sooth, thou much errest.
I never saw that person (Except one,
Who justly claimed my love, now dead and gone)
In whose embracements I would sooner lock the treasures of my heart.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Now, now, she's coming.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: If you had moved my ears with a chaste suit, I should have listened.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Brave! she's mine already.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I cannot love thee now.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p:
No, I cannot
conceive a good thought of thee.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I hate thee.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Heigh? handy, dandy, fast and loose, brave devil.
I'll conjure you for this. Come, will you love me?
Or no matter for your love, will you lie with me?
Do, or lie alone i'th meadow here. I shall leave your tempting eyes for the crows to pick out.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Defend me goodness.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Whistle not so loud, lest I cut your pipe, come on.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Honour or life, how shall I save you both?
Sir, I shall spoil you. I ha' bene long a sinner.
A common sinner, sir, and am not sound.
You cannot scape infection, if you touch me.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Humh! the pox, say you? well, you'll not reveal me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You need not, sir, distrust my silence. Wrongs
That scape heaven's hand, need not fear mortal tongs.
This world's turned bedlam, raving, desperate-bad.
It staggered drunk before, now it runs mad.
More customers?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: But, sir, respect your life, your conscience.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Thou sayest well, for my life. But for my conscience ▪ 'tis like a surgeon's, that takes money for letting out blood. Think of my mortgage.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Upon my life, he'll kill her. O presumption,
How dost thou dare heaven's justice? I must study
To interpose prevention. Sir, I'm your son:
This breast you gave me, and I'll still conserve it,
A faithful closet to lock up your secrets.
How will you strike? Pistol her?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: No: that speaks
Like an obstreperous advocate, too loud,
In th'cares of justice. Murder, like your Jesuit,
Should whisper death in silence — sleeping silence.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I apprehend it, poison. Sir, I'll buy you
A speedy potion.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Not too dear, good son.
I would not have't too dear: my money's gone.
Two pennyworth of ratsbane, w' have experience,
We'll do't; do't thoroughly.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I'll provide it, sir.
I'll be your apothecary; but by no means
minister it myself. You must do that, sir:
I cannot do you better service. Rare!
Then bring my father to the Jailhouse.
Be petulant, and let your wanton mirth,
Give you forgetful of all wrong.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Come widow, I forgive thee now: I hope thou'lt forgive me too. I'm come to drink down all malice.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Pray sir, lead the way. I'll follow.
Look up, dear friend: what thus dejects you?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Wonders, miracles — I must needs poison thee.
Be not dismayed, my poison shall not hurt thee:
I'll tell thee all ▪

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Hostess, pray 'Help me to the money quickly. I must pay't instantly.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You shall sir.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: So, if my newborn plots hold constant life ▪
I'll cheat my thieves, but above all, my wife.
sp.stage: Enter wife and Rob. with money.
sp.l: Thank you, good widow. Youth, tell the
Gentlemen I'm gone to tender the money. bid
sp.p: 'Em be merry and continue their healths. I'll take my round, when I come again. Farewell Ostice.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You're welcome sir,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Gone, sayst thou? and with the money? fire and gunpowder! how are we blown up?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Pretty handsome!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ostice —

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Good leech, stand further off: your breath's too violent ▪

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Did we not charge you not to deliver the money, but to us all three together?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Mass, 'tis true. How forgetfully are we cheated?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are a cozening woman.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You do lie!

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Keep the peace. Ostice, you'll make it good to us, three hundred pound, a pretty competent sum.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Furies and fiends! wits, you do fairly strive.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: I thought this fairy money would ne'er thrive.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I have heard all this roguery.
Cheer, widow: let not sorrow make thee sick.
Perhaps, I'll catch the knaves at their own trick.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p:
So ho-my master's turned reveller. I never lost my name
since I came into his service, till now. Uck! A miracle, I am not thirsty.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Now my wise kindred, why look you so pale?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O, I'll put off my wedding. I will not for all Bedford marry tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: No? why?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O, my uncle reaching for a cup, overthrew the salt towards me — towards me. O 'tis ominous.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: The falling of a salt keep thee from marriage! well, I have a strange medicine, of quick cure to this conceited sickness. Robin, fetch me some wine. Coz, how dost feel thyself?

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: He shakes as if he had the burning ague.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Perplexed cousin, perplexed. I had rather a good lordship had fallen towards me.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Tut man, salt seasons all things; fish or flesh.
And troth, thou needest it: for thy wit's but fresh.
Here blood, I drink to thee.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Now could I dance like a Dutch froe: my heels are as light as my head.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O I recant. Cousin, I will marry.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: What meant you sir, to spill the wine upon him?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: 'Twas a mischance sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: No: it was good hap.
'Tis a good sign, to have wine spilt in ones lap:
This makes amends for the salt, sir.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I thought this dock would fetch your nettle out.
I see. small wind turns a fool's mill about. Let's go.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yonder comes my physician and his potion.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I have here two papers: one of sugar, and that's for myself: another of poison, and that's for my Ostice. Let me be right-right. I should make fair work, if I were mistaken now. Ha widow! th' art a churl a— very churl, that wouldst not keep company with thy guests. I ha' brought thee a cup of wine here: health and blood to thee, sweet widow.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: A miracle: an usurer drunk at's own cost.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: There's a whole cup for thee: pledge me chuck. Nay tarry, tarry: thou must have sugar to 't; women love sweet things, I know. So, off with't bottom and all: the deeper the sweeter. Ha Ostice, my son shall give thee a lease of thine inn.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I would he could grant me a lease of my life: for I grow sick sir. Robin, look in.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: (Excellent ratsbane) it works already. Widow, dost remember since thou wast in my study? and i'faith what foundst there?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nothing, but what I left behind me, sir. I'm very sick.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: (I'll ne'er trust poison else.) This cottons well yet. No sooner dead, but my son shall cease on all the goods. Search the coffers for my mortgage. If it be lost, yet now she I keep counsel.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: This wine hath made me thirsty: I'm not well.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Hie thee to bed and sweat. A little posset with twopenny worth of horse-spice. O 'tis excellent to put one into a sweat. Farewell widow.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: So I'm recovered now: thy absence cures me.
O earth! thou centre of the world and sin;
Tasty paradise is lost t'th'art only now
A larger stable, where all vices dwell.
Did not the sun shine, I should think thee hell.
sp.p: Lucky! here comes the cheater. Sir, the money is asked for by the gentlemen, your friends: they threaten to arrest me, but I hope sir, you'll be my quittance.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Yes: on this condition.
Let me enjoy thy love on this soft ground:
I'll pay it back, were it three hundred pound.
Stir not: this chargeth you: are you not content?
Come, with a silent kiss seal your consent.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sir, you know my disease. I'm dangerous.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p:
The pox? O I have known London too long to be
afraid of the pox. Come, will you unlock? I ha' the golden key. If not, I'll to Virginia, like some cheating bankrupt, and leave my creditor ith' suds. You know the jail. Ha you never been hired to yawl for the whole prison? and whule to the passengers?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sorcerer, thy circle cannot hold me.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: No, I would have yours hold me. Come, will you fadge?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Not, if thou killst me: not if thy murderous hand
Could put me to a death ▪ (Like Jesuits' poison)
Ten years a dying.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: No? you will repent.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: So wilt thou never: take my carcase, slave:
Whiles there's a soul within; no lustful hand
Did or shall ever touch it.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Politic whore!
What do you ken me now?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: My husband? O,
Into your arms I fly.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Infection, no.
Y' are dangerous by your own confession.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Alas! I forged that answer, to avoid
Sinful embracings. Brothels sick indeed
Of that contagion, sooth and smother't up,
To tempt distrustful comers on, at once
To their own profit, and the others ruin.
They speak false, to do false the safer. I
To save my conscience did my flesh bely.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: You cannot tempt me Siren; I am resolute.
Thou art a cunning bitch, and I am proud
Of such expected means to my revenge.
Hark, how I'll quittance thy abhorred lusts.
First, thou shalt be arrested for the money,
Whereof I cheated thee: so be restrained
From thy old straggling, mewed up like a haggard;
Till the assize comes, than thou shalt be hanged.
I hear thou standst bound over for suspicion
Of robbing gripe. I did the villainy.
I'll have't proved thine: so thou shalt hang for me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Dear husband, do so.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Husband me no more:
That name was cancelled when you first played whore.
Now garden-pot, you water your sad fears,
But I am no love-fool, won with woman's tears.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O prosecute your will. Thus on my knees,
And with a heart more humbled, I entreat,
And I must have it granted ere I rise;
Be pleased to make this life a sacrifice,
To expiate your wrath. I freely yield it,
For your redemption. For your hate I die;
That might not live in your love's company.
If I confess not guilty, to save you,
Imagine then all your suspicions true.
But when for your debts I have paid this life,
Believe but then, you had a faithful wife.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: O, thou wouldst melt a rock. My heart's too dead,
To sprout at this wet April. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Peace and content attend you: and let still
Mercy forgive, and rectify your ill.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: What? not dead yet? but weeping? come, come dry
Up all thy tears: go hie thee in, and die.
Much villainy is now together packed.
The scene grows full. Your patience this last act.

div.head: Act. Quint.
div.stage: Enter old brace, the true abbot. Abbot.
div.l: To man, how sweet is breath! yet sweetest of all,
That breath, which from his native air doth fall.
How many weary pases have I measured!
How many known and unknown dangers passed,
Since I commenced my tedious pilgrimage,
The last great work of my death-yielding age!
Yet am I blessed, that my returning bones
Shall be raked up in England's peaceful earth.
O happy Englishmen, if your sore eyes
Did not look squint on your felicities!
How other countries envy, what you loathe,
And surfeit on: and would make that their pride,
Which is by your contempt still vilefied!
This sickness fullness breeds in most men's blood;
None less, than the possessors, know what's good.
Now to my deputy: here his glories end.
But stay: he comes to meet me. I'll attend.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Confound this damned fox: he has cheated me of the best prey, I ever sharked for. Would I could light on him; I have a constable here should make him stand.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: What's this? sharking, foxing, and a pistol?
Th'emblem of thief, cheater, murderer?
Sure, this vile eldern was not of my planting.
I know him: 'tis his brother, to whose trust I did infeoff my place.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: I was directed this way to the abbot.
My lord — the judge detained by sickness from tomorrow's session, desires your lordship's aid to the supply of his own place. Th' assistant justices rest their determining sentence on your lips.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: I'll give my old attendance.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Your lordship's leave.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I leave your lordship too.
I must about this mischief to prevent:
I'll force you both your offices repent.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.p: So, so, so. My customers drop in roundly. Welcome, Mr. Gripe, and the rest of my good friends, welcome! I am very glad to see you here. My house was not graced with an usurer, and under-sheriff, many a day before; though I ha' been pestered with abundance of honester fellows. Speak, shall's be merry? what will you have to dinner?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: A rope. What dost thou tell me of dinner?

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.p: No sir, that shall be kept for your supper.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Give me so me sack and aqua vitae. I will be drunk presently.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: It's clear. I have twenty cases for't.
The concealing of murder is but manslaughter. I must ha' my book.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Give is some sack, I say: must tut, etc.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: My uncle committed? Justice itself sent to the jail?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Cousin, sweet cousin, run, scud, fly — to sir bore notwithstanding: he lies but three miles off; he's in my debt: bid him release me, and I'll release him.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: Stay sir. He's in my debt too: I ha' solicited for sir bore these seven years, and have nothing but bare thanks.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Nay then, take me with you. Thus —
sp.stage: Enter Benjamin, Robin, thirsty; thirsty climbing up into a tree. Rob. into a bush.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ha you your lesson perfect?

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Yes, yes: as a midwife her errand to a citizen's wife. There's not an owl in an ivy-bush, nor a parrot at a drugster's door, has who whoop, or walk knave, more perfect.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Robin, do't cunningly. My dad shall be
Only to me beholding for his life.
By that advantage I recall his love.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Cousin, fly every step. Remember, like a juryman, you go upon life and death.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Happiness grant, that no hare cross him ith' way: his superstitious legs will retire, though we hang for't. Come, shall we keep the rule of the place, and drink drunk now?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Now kindred, whither trot you so fast?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O cousin, about a deed of charity; to save your father, and two or three knaves more from hanging. I am going to sir bore notwithstanding; to save them out of prison: they have saved him often.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Sir bore notwithstanding, he's a great man, cousin.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: He had three lordships fell to him at a clap; the worst worth 400. a year.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Yet he's bare notwithstanding.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: He has sold his caroche with four Flanders mares, because he would retire himself and live ith' country.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Yet he's bare notwithstanding. But to himself cousin, farewell.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: To him, quoth he? I will to him, were the devil in my way.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Pork, pork.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: The devil pork you. What dismal bird croaks disaster to my journey!

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Pork.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nay, if the destinies have set the raven against me, I'll return sure — yet let me see. So my uncle may be hanged, I'll on, come what will.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Pork.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: O this black bird tolls like a passing-bell,
My own sad mischief and my uncle's knell.
Yet why am I so timorous; when charity
Bids me go on, shall a raven hinder me?
I'll keep aloof and pass — o a spirit, a spirit.
The widow's ghost. Bromley, lawyer, uncle, hang.
Take all your fortunes, I'll no further gang.
It's an unhallowed place, a dismal day.
Betide what will, I'll back again some way.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Come down, raven.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Come out, spirit.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Blind, credulous fool! He that shall trust at need
Such nice and tottering coxcombs, shall thus speed.
Should his sick father send him for some drugs,
He would turn back at such imagined bugs.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Come, mother, friend, and wife; take these back places,
Where you may hear unseen: that when time serves,
I may produce you. Works and hours are spent
Then well, when we do good, or ill prevent.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: I cannot judge, what is this day's success.
All-ruling powers the doubtful sequel bless.
sp.stage: Enter curfew with other assistants, Vaster in a priest's habit, Valentine like a physician, the jailor with Gripe, Bromley, Griffin, etc.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: My lord, whose place I personate, being sick,
Hath thus designed me, both to hear and censure
The criminal causes, which offend the peace
Of our dread sovereign, and his subjects' weal.
Whiles we lance ulcers, we the body heal.
The charge I give in short, you of the jury,
Look to your oath and conscience: let not favour
Shut up your eyes, nor malice open them
Too wide. You understand, our laws are good.
'Tis pity that they should be writ in blood.
But since connivance at unlawful deeds
Gives but encouragement, and we cannot strike
With sword of justice the deserving faults,
Except you give the persons to our hands:
all on your vigilant information stands.
Proceed to the inditements.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: We are all cast away. Sir bare is not come.

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.l: Pull down that counterfeit, proud, arrogant, puff:
Could your intrusion not content itself
T'usurp my office, but you must abuse
The King's deputed judge?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Down with him, down with him.

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.l: Jailor, receive him to your custody,
Till our just censure give him punishment.
Fox, I shall hunt you out.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: Do't with a pox.
The goose sometimes must sit and judge the fox.

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.p: Proceed; the day hastens.

sp.speaker: Clark.
sp.p: Marian sorrow widow, yield thy body, and save thy bail.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Sir, she is dead: her felony is answered before a higher court.

sp.speaker: Clarke.
sp.p: That is the woman that gripe is suspected to have poisoned. Godfrey gripe stand to the bar. You are indicted for the murder of Marian sorrow widow: guilty or not?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Not guilty, my lord: let all the world testify of my honest carriage. I have lived all my days in good name and fame.

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.l: Stand not upon your credit and good deeds.
Your harvest would be small, if like your seeds.
If all that know thee stood about this place,
And had free liberty to speak their thoughts,
Round echoing curses would amaze thy soul,
And with hell's damned crew thy name enroll.
But when the widow, orphan call for plagues
On thy black life, thou highest unto thy bags;
there dost applaud and hug thy wretched self:
As solace 'gainst all woes lay in thy pelf.
Thou hast no god but gold: that deity
Thou shouldst adore, and would still succour thee,
Is quite rejected. And that idol, money,
Which bears away thy confidence and heart,
When thou art plagued, aggravates thy smart.
Thou art the devil's executioner.
His rankest plague on earth's an usurer.
Spirits in hell whip souls: extorting slaves
Torment poor bodies so before their graves.
Thou art a gulf, poor men's estates to drink.
A quagmire; none pass o'er thee, but they sink.
Unless strepsiades-like, men could devise
To pluck the moon by sorcery from the skies;
Thy month and gain will come. Like some at sea,
(Yet dangerless of shipwreck more than they)
Thou slumberest in a base lethargic swoon.
Let others toil, thy journey's done as soon.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Will not this move him?

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.l: Nature in all inferior things hath set
A pitch or term, when they no more shall get
Increase and offspring. Unrepaired houses
Fall to decay: old cattle cease to breed.
And sapless trees deny more fruit or seed.
The earth would heartless and infertile be,
If it should never have a jubilee.
Only the usurer's money genders still:
The longer, lustier: age this doth not kill.
He lives to see his money's moneys money,
Even to a hundred generations reach.
He, whiles his interest money in does troll,
Cares not to lose the principal, his soul.
He like a cleanly alchemist can soak
And draw much silver, yet waste none in smoke.
Thou lendest, like water poured on seacoal fire,
Or on a load of lime a shower of rain.
sp.p: It seems to cool heat, but doth more inflame.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: His conscience has deaf ears.

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.l: When all is done,
And thou hast swelled thy heaps; to say no more,
Thy coffer's only rich, and thou art poor.
This common plague is on all usurers shown:
They've much, yet are not masters of their own.
One day thy stintless mind shall have enough;
When the divided pieces of thyself
Shall in their several doomed mansions dwell:
Enough of mould in grave, of fire in hell.
But I spend breath in vain; come, let's proceed.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: No further. You have made my conscience bleed.
I here confess myself guilty of all,
Even of this murder too.

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: Let mercy fall on thy distressed soul. Now to the rest.

sp.speaker: Clark.
sp.p: Nicholas Bromley, you are indicted for the murder of William Sager, etc. Guilty or not?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Not guilty? Who testifies against me!

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.l: In case of murder should we never judge
By circumstantial likelihoods and presumptions,
No life could be secure.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Puff! shift for yourselves; sir bore notwithstanding dares not be seen.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: O, I am lost.
My lord, I'm guilty: so is Griffin too:
He did conceal the fact, that I did do,
We shared the lands together.

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.l: Powerful truth!
Murder will out, though by the actor's mouth.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: O Benjamin, I have undone
My life, my state, my credit, and my son.
But I'm resolved to die, so monarchs must:
Rich men as well as poor, must turn to dust.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: methinks I could prevent all this.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Alas, thou lovest me; but 'tis not possible.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Sir, I have here a book already drawn,
Seal to it freely, and I'll save your life.
You shall confirm me your undoubted heir,
And then surrender vasters mortgaged lands.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: My lord and all this bench be witness to it.
Then thus I quit you, widow, appear in court.
In earnest, see, she lives, that died in sport.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir, thank your drugster, else I had died by you.
And you for me received a murderer's due.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: So, I am cozened finely, finely —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: My lord, I challenge this widow for cheating me of 300. pounds. This is one of her old tricks.

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My lord, myself and two entrusted friends
Came hither to pay money on a bond,
Whiles the receiver did defer his coming;
We gave this cozening woman, being hostess,
The whole sum to lay up: and straight charged her,
Not to deliver't, but to us all together.
She says one of us three demanded it
Of her in haste, and ran away: and thus
We lost our money, and the bond lies forfeit.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Your lordship's leave. 'tis true, she not denies,
But they so charged her, and she was so cozened.
Therefore she yields to payment. Let 'em come
All three together, they shall have the money.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Upon my faith, a pretty quillet.

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.l: Witty and just. How say you? here produce
The other two, your satisfaction's ready.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: The widow's cleared: but master Valentine —
Nay, man, come nearer, you'd have present pay.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, sir, let it even go.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: So must not you.
You gave 300. pound to her: 'tis true.
Which like a subtle quacksalver, you robbed
My father of; sprites, fairies —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I am cobbed.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: It's true, my lord: this is one of the fairies. Justice, justice.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well, if there be no remedy, I hope,
I shall not dance alone upon the rope.
My lord, here's the other fairy.

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.l: O sir, have I found you?
Pull off that borrowed habit from his back.
O that such foul deeds should be hid in black.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: My lord, this widow's accessary too:
She plotted, she received. Justice, justice.

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.l: But late thy song was mercy, now all justice?
Here's all the goodness of an usurer.
She saved his life, he would now hang her.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: She has robbed me, undone me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It is most true, my lord, she plotted all.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: (Your villainy, Ostice, we shall now retort.
You cheated us, and we will hang you for't.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: How do these mischiefs grow, like Hidra's heads, faster by cutting off!

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Prodigious villains! will they thus cast away an innocent woman?
Yet I most vile of all, that thus stand by,
And for my fault behold my poor wife die.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: My lord, upon my soul this woman's clear:
And only malice thus accuseth her.

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.p: Speak, woman, art thou guilty?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: My lord, I beg a word with my confessor,
Than I shall answer. Sir, a word in private.
Now vaster, open thy unbelieving eyes:
Lo, thy devoted wife for thy sin dies.
Yield but this kindness to my latest breath,
Thou hat'st me living, love me yet in death.
Farewell — my lord, I will not say, I'm guilty;
Do as your evidence and wisdom leads you.

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.p: This knot is hard to undo.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: My lord, I'll help you.
Lo, I am that third fairy, that pronounce
This woman clear, and those two perjured knaves.
We three are guilty: let your sentence come.
I have deserved, will not despair my doom.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: My lord, he says not true: he's innocent: I guilty.

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.p: Speak on your souls, which of these tongues speak truth.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Curf. My lord, the woman's clear.

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.l: Pernicious villains, hopeless to be good:
That thus have striven to spill the guiltless blood.
Widow, you're quit. Sir, wait you your doom.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: With patience. Benjamin gripe, I here accuse you for murdering Richard vaster.

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: My lord, I found that vaster dying, buried him,
Saw him receiving death by this man's sword.
Theft's a great sin, but murder most abhorred.

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.p: Speak; is this possible?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: We met in single combat in the field:
It seems his life unto my sword did yield.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Ay me, my father slain?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: And by his friend?
Fate, whither will thy projects tend!

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: My husband's hand my father's life undoes:
For this fact he must die: thus both I lose.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Forgive me all, by me you all have lost,
The wife a husband, children a dear parent:
Thus I return you all some recompense.
Nan thou shalt lose a husband.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Heavens defend.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Mother, you lose a son, brother a friend.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Can nature so degenerate, that a man should live, stand by, and see another suffer for murdering him?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Once again off disguise.
My lord, thus I prevent this feared disaster
My second case pulled off, I am plain vaster.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: My father?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: My dear husband.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Most, most dear friend.
My love to you doth beyond bounds extend.
My lord, first to this honourable bench,
I' here present the Kings most gracious pardon
For us three here: heaven no less pardon us.
Now to my wife: see wench, I am new born;
Wrenched from the plague of a suspected horn.
Black jaundices of the mind, thou feigned spirit,
That haunts men's quiet thoughts with troubling shades.
Pernicious jealousy, that like needless physic
Divertest health to voluntary sickness,
I brush thee off like dust. See, I am now
New married to my love and to my life.
Never could man boast a more constant wife.
Dear Benjamin, now son, what I have left
Of all my shipwrecked fortunes, shall be thine.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Resume your former state, my father yields it.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Thanks to your honesty, not his; yet thus,
Some means of satisfaction I have found;
I'll pay him back his lost three hundred pound:
The fairy money, which was just the price
Of my redeemed lands.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Now master Bromley,
That universal mercy to our guilt,
May be afforded, and no blood be spilt:
Surrender up your lease for the three lives
To Sager's wife and children, and I'll quit you.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: I do most freely yield it.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: Sager lives,
And hearty thanks for your forced kindness gives.

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.l: Happy delusions! in such ways of ill,
I wish men may be thus mistaken still.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Ravens, and sprites, and fairies, and hares and diuels-thus have I lost my wench, lost my money, lost my watch, lost my wits. I do here renounce the faith of all almanacs, physiogmoners, palmists, fortune-tellers. Erra pater was an ass, and so are prognosticators, his children, from generation to generation.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: I have drunk powerful physic, and the dropsy
of my (Till now) never quenched avarice,
Dries up like dew at the ascending sun.
Vaster, take back your lands; and for the money,
Give it my son in portion with your daughter.
Henceforth I'll study to requite the wrongs,
Which I have done poor men by usury,
And vomit up th'extortions, that do lie
As undigested crudities on my conscience.
My future life shall be in mercy spent.
I'm gripe no more; that name I do repent.

sp.speaker: Abbot
sp.l: All chronicles be filled with this; and let it
Be as a wonder to all ears imparted.
England had once an usurer converted.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: The session now dissolves: each justice rises:
No hurt is done; this is the mild assizes.
We have scaped fair thus far: yet there remains
A stronger judgement to pass on our pains.
Too much to hope or doubt we must not dare.
We humbly then stand at your censures bar.
If the worst comes that may be, yet I look
For this grace, to be saved by my book.
But if with your applause our merit stands:
Faith then be friends with us, and give's your hands.

A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length.
